Today I've finally made up for lost time, but unfortunately I was a tad disappointed. The story about a bunch of kids trying to trace a pirate's treasure has all the potential in the world, but all this old trilobite got out of this movie was a migraine. There's so much high-pitched screaming going on in this movie I've turned on my alarm clock just to relax a little. And generally I have nothing against stereotypes, but come on: 80% of the fat kid's lines is about food, the Asian kid invents gadgets, it's just sorta painful here. Why these characters get so much attention while the at the time still cool Corey Feldman barely gets to do anything is beyond me. The movie's obviously well-made and it definitely has some bright spots (Sloth!), but you just miss the heart-warming friendship between boys you saw in things like "Stand By Me" or "The Lost Boys". Not my cup of tea.
The plot for this thing is straight out of an "Our Gang" comedy short. It's creaky and foolish and relies on stereotypes to give life to the characters.I wouldn't waste time with this if I were you.

It's funny how some things can click with you, while others don't. Personally, I love the darker 80s movies. The Terminator, Highlander, Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, et cetera. But for some reason I can't stand the comedies of that decade at all.The Goonies being a fine example. I mean, I get why it's popular. It has that Spielbergian charm to it. Small town Americana, young geeks finding their voice, affable villains who you love to hate. A lost treasure to be found, quirky characters, a good message.Yet I don't like it. I think all of the kids are either weeps or seriously creepy. Corey Feldman's Clark "Mouth" Devereaux is definitely the worst of the latter category. The way this preteen hits on women thrice his age is just messed up. It's supposed to come across as quirky and funny, but it's not. It's creepy. Jonathan Ke Huy Quan as Richard "Data" Wang is also weird in how he doesn't fit in. Here's a little kid that would put Inspector Gadget to shame, yet he's in this movie that has more in common with a tame Stephen King novel. His "inventions" steal most of the scenes they feature in, but not in a good way.That being said, all the characters are identifiable. I also like how the villains are really rather incompetent and kind of morons. Makes them funnier to watch and gives them personality.I can see why people like the film. It just isn't for me.

reviews.review_title: "Goonies" is a kids classic with a Spielberg-sized imagination and heart
reviews.content: As much as "The Goonies" is distinctly an 80s film, there's no denying that sense of timelessness about it as a kids adventure film. It's got buried treasure, creepy yet conveniently klutzy bad guys, and that archetypal rag-tag group of kids who all go by nicknames. That's pretty much the foundation for live action kids movies for at least the next decade. Unfortunately, that kind of kids' entertainment has fallen by the wayside to make way for CGI in this century, but that shouldn't cheat "The Goonies" of its sense of magic, mystery and the courage of children who refuse to let rationality plague their thinking while they're still young."The Goonies" follows a group of kids on the Oregon coast, all with their own amusing quirks, as they search for a treasure that would give them enough money to save their homes from being bought out by the wealthy folks in town. There's Mikey (Sean Astin), the fearless leader, Mouth (Corey Feldman), the smart-ass, Data (Jonathan Ke Quan) the crazy gadget nerd and Chunk (Jeff Cohen) the rotund, hunger-driven, paranoid, klutz. When the boys escape, they're followed by Mikey's older brother Brand (Josh Brolin) and his love interest, Andy--the teenage friendly subplot. Of course the treasure is buried beneath the house of some insanely creepy murderers named the Fratellis who are completely stupid yet no less creepy. Joe Pantoliano plays one of them. They're your standard villains and perfect for the fantasy element of the movie. Obviously this film tries to play off producer/writer Steven Spielberg's success with Indiana Jones by setting up underground cave booby traps as the kids go after the treasure. This is a very funny movie in both the cute family way and clever way too. The humor that comes from these kids is fun for children viewers because it's visual and funny for adults because of what comes out of their mouths. While this is mostly a boys-oriented film, it's definitely intended for families, although I was surprised by the swearing of some of the kids in the film.Considering Spielberg, Richard Donner (one of the 80s most famous directors) and future Harry Potter director Chris Columbus all played a part in the creation of this film, it should be no surprise this film has the imagination and the talent behind it to work on all these levels for all these different audiences. While I do think the movie kind of fizzles in the last half hour with all the focus on the treasure and escaping, the rest is so strong that you can get through it easily. This is simply a kids/family classic.

It's been over 30 years since I last watched The Goonies. We had a copy on well worn VHS that came out of its box most weekends. You'd think then that I'd remember it well. The gist yes, but the details have been erased, which is what makes reliving it so much fun. It's not a great film, but it's different when you discover something as a child, the quality doesn't matter as much, it's something that speaks to you regardless. Now I grew up in Manchester, far from this seemingly exciting American suburb on the screen. The kids think their town is boring, but to me it was another world. One with big unusual looking houses, wide streets, bikes and adventure. Oh boy the adventure, the Spielberg kind (credited as a co-writer, but his stamp is all over it), wondrous and over the top. The Goonies live in a space without parents, although their escapades are in aid of them, but the screen time is all theirs, misfit kids on a treasure trail intent on making the most of "our time". Cue hefty doses of slapstick, teen movie tropes, booby traps, a rousing fantasy score and smaltzy sentimentality. I'd be lying if I said I enjoyed this as much as I did when I was a kid, but honestly it was close, it really stands up, good clean full blown fun. Childhood wonder should never leave you and Goonies... never die.

reviews.review_title: A nostalgic, timeless and powerful classic
reviews.content: I can still remember my dad putting a VHS tape of this movie on when I was a kid, I loved it! The title and initial intro was slightly off-putting but it's one of those movies that you have to watch the whole thing of to really appreciate it. Sure, it's a little weird at times, there's a few crude jokes (the statue, oh my god), but at a closer look you'll see that it's a story about friendship and childhood adventures, something you never get too old to remember.The Goonies is one of those films that either you love, or you hate. I love it and I hope it isn't lost among the sea of bad remakes of other movie classics popping up in the 21st century. I hope other generations get to experience this film (though at that point it may be outdated since kids today are lazy as heck and slaves to Apple Inc.). This movie is somewhat of a cult film, it has a fanbase of people who grew up with it and love it and it's becoming more popular as a nostalgic relic.

reviews.review_title: This is an all time great movie in American cinematic history
reviews.content: The Goonies (1985) is a movie my daughter and I recently watched together on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a group of kids who are about to lose their homes when real-estate developers come in and their parents can't afford to keep their properties. One of the kid's fathers runs the local museum and while looking through some artifacts he comes across a treasure map and the kids follow it hoping to save their families; meanwhile, a group of killers/bandits escape from prison and catch wind of the children's plans and are hot on their trail.This movie is directed by Richard Donner (Lethal Weapon) and stars Sean Astin (Lord of the Rings), Josh Brolin (No Country for Old Men), Corey Feldman (Lost Boys), Joe Pantoliano (Bad Boys), Robert Davi (Die Hard), Anne Ramsey (Throw Mama from the Train), Kerri Green (Summer Rental) and Lupe Ontiveros (As Good As It Gets).The storyline and characters in this are so magical. The writing is brilliant and the characters are put in hilarious circumstances. The Chuckle Shuffle, the tricycle scene, Feldman speaking Spanish and every scene with Sloth were all legendary. Data was always my favorite character in this but they are all so good. The special effects, props and sets were so cool and the soundtrack was perfect. The ending gives you a fulfilling feeling.Overall this is an all time great movie in American cinematic history. This is an absolute must see and an easy 10/10.

I went to see Goonies on the big screen back in 2019 for it's 34th anniversary 4K screening. As someone who wasn't around in 85 to watch it getting to see it on the big screen in this generation was a dream come true.The movie still holds up as one of the best movies made and today still inspires people and makes people smile.It is well shot and the cast is perfect as a band of kids known as the goonies hunt for a lost treasure to save there homes it's a great adventure for all ages and is a true classic.If by some miracle you haven't already seen this masterpiece watch it and join the Goonies around the world who love this classic tale.

reviews.review_title: Unspeakably vile-everything that's nauseating about Spielberg films
reviews.content: If you like hackneyed,inspiration-free plots straight out of best-forgotten children's fiction featuring a gaggle of unlovely,shrieking,white-bread American Kids boasting all the charm of a waterspout at a sewage farm, this is surely the film for you. Me,I'd rather watch somebody else watch paint dry. Everything that repels me about Spielberg is in this repugnant waste of celluloid - the cutesy sentimentalised, middle-American vision of childhood, the corny "humour", the utter predictability, but more than anything the incessant screaming and shrieking by the fat-faced,horrid,horrid little kids,who,in a more enlightened age would've been slaughtered at birth. Anyone who really appreciates cinema - both populist AND serious should rightly reject cynical junk like this.

Goonies... Where do I begin? This movie is the ultimate tressure hunt for one eyed willies gold. An amazing movie if I must say, many well known actors of the 80s, I love the plot, the comedy, the music, literally everything about it is spot on.Definitely watch this if you haven't already, even if you have its worth another ain't it :)

reviews.review_title: a juvenile iteration of Indian Jones-esque treasure-hunting adventure is close to the mark
reviews.content: "The young cast's performance is uniformly engaging and occasionally hilarious, Astin is especially earnest and precociously sagacious in his screen debut (no wonder he created such a hoopla by guest-starring in the second season of STRANGER THINGS), Feldman cunningly exhibits a savvy aptitude that makes an impressive entrance but is mostly underutilized when the cat-and-mouse chase begins, but it is Cohen who is saddled with the most grueling task of acting in the face of incessant grotesque, hectoring and menace, which he pulls it off magnificently without losing his funny bone."read my full review on my blog: cinema omnivore, thanks

I didn't like this Steven Spielberg-produced cute-fest when I was twelve. I like it even less now. Pretty much any Gen-X-er is familiar with the movie's plot: seven kids (including future Lord of the Rings star Sean Astin, future has-been Corey Feldman, and future indie actress Martha Plympton) venture into the caves of Astoria's Cannon Beach in search of a long lost treasure supposedly hidden by a legendary pirate hundreds of years ago. There are a few good moments along the way and Richard Donner directs the action scenes with his usual zing, but the kids' performances range from irritating to just plain lousy. The characters are worn out clichés (the shy book-worm winds up the hero, the fat kid is a pig, the Asian kid is an inventor, etc), and the Chris Columbus screenplay is dull, predictable and uneven. It's saved somewhat thanks to terrific performances by Anne Ramsey, Robert Davi and Joe Pantaliano as the bad guys, not to mention more than a few glimpses of Kelli Green's underpants. The DVD includes the legendary octopus scene--and it's very clear why the filmmakers chose to cut it out. This, of course makes the scene at the end when the kids yell "the octopus was scary" make no sense, and anyone who isn't aware that there was once an octopus scene will think the kids are making up stories, when they have no reason to after all they've been through! I simply do not see in this movie what apparently every other person my age does. Sorry.

The Goonies is a must-see for anyone who love movies, it is a treasure. The film is about a batch of kids named The Goonies who find a treasure map in a attic. When one of them realise that this may actually lead them to treasure he and his buddies decide to go on a fascinating hunt for it in a effort to save them from being forced out of their homes. Along the way they meet three crooks and Sloth- a lovable character who makes friends with the "truffle shuffle kid" Chunk, after he is caught by the crooks, and together they go looking for his friends to rescue them. So i advise you, anyone who has not seen this movie watch it as you will certainly be missing out otherwise. You will like this movie if you like films such as "The Never-Ending Story", "Legend", "Gremlins" and "Labyrinth"

I don't think I knew a single kid when I was little that didn't have Goonies as one of their favorite movies and I am fairly certain that, today, the adults my age--of the male persuasion--that don't still feel the same are the people that have no since of fun, take everything too seriously, and turn their noses up at the Sabatini collection in their local library.I used to want to live here when I was little. I mean, not only could I be one of the Goonies, but Arnold Schwarzenegger would be my Kindergarten teacher, I could meet Johnny-5, and give a home to Benji.Astoria was a magic place where all your childhood fantasies came true.Especially The Goonies. It was the adventure high of a childhood filled with adventure movies, cartoons, comics, and eventually books.Pirate Treasure, a kid with inventions, bad guys, close friends, a pirate ship, all in the same town that has Kindergarten Cops and robots with lazers.It is literally every kids dream...and unfortunately, like the Ghostbusters, one that will be killed in a remake.DO NOT REMAKE THIS MOVIE. If you want to make money from it, re-release it. DO NOT REMAKE THIS FILM.

Crossing this off my list of shame and... I'm left wondering about one of two things. Does this film require nostalgia or was I simply in the wrong headspace to properly appreciate it. As I watched, I struggled to stay interested. As it progressed, I couldn't seem to connect to the material. An eccentric group of kids going on an insane adventure in search of pirate gold? I wanted to like it, I just could get drawn into it all. I kept wondering when it would get good when it would kick into gear and do something warranting its iconic cult standing.In the end, it just seemed like an alright movie. Creative, but not knocking my socks off by any means. It was fine. Just fine. I give it credit for creativity and being different and yet, that's the only thing I really appreciated. Oh, that and Short Round running about as the gizmo gadgeteer. Might try this another day, see if it clicks more but as it stands... Eh.

I liked this movie when I was a kid but watching as a adult it's well meh there's a bit in the movie where they play In a piano in a cave and bits of the cave fall away I was thinking how do they that cave in the first place but the rest of the movie is well slow best kept as a memory of the past I susspose.

reviews.review_title: Quite silly at times but mostly good fun
reviews.content: Quite silly at times but mostly good fun.A group of kids set out to find a legendary buried treasure in their small home town. All they have to go by is a several centuries-old map. As if things weren't already difficult enough, there's a band of hardened criminals after them too...A fairly uneven movie. Is a decent adventure with some great moments, especially comedic moments, and some rollicking good fun, but is also quite silly at times. There's so many scenes that are random at best and sub-plots that add nothing to the movie. Anything involving the character Chunk you knew would just be plain irritating and involve a lot of mindless screaming...Performances vary too. There are some stars-of-the-future in the cast - Josh Brolin, Sean Astin, Corey Feldman, Martha Plimpton - and they give solid performances. However, consistent with the irritating nature of the character he played, Jeff Cohen almost ruins the show as Chunk. Kids will love the movie. Adults may be a bit more subdued in their views.
Great kids movie and it is a shame that movies like this aren't made anymore. Great journey with a lot of fun and with some adult messages.

After 25+ years, I finally watched this movie with my daughter and after 45 minutes I had to leave the room. The CONSTANT screaming and yelling by all the characters was more than I could take. The dialog was stupid, the characters over-acted, the fat kid was annoying as hell, and the amount of plot holes made this laughable at best. The premise of the movie is great...a remake could do well, but as this stands I couldn't stand to hear one more second of it.And seriously, they cast Martha Plimpton??? Of all the struggling actors in Hollywood, this is who they picked? I guess they needed a homely girl that couldn't act, so they picked her (with Kerri Green being a close second).

A group of kids in the attic discovers a treasure map from the seventeenth century and goes in search of the lost pirate ship. A children's adventure, typical of the '80s, reminiscent of movies about Indiana Jones or the "Pirates of the Caribbean". It's nothing special, but it's interesting, witty and nicely shot.7/10

reviews.review_title: A timeless adventure for kids and adults alike...
reviews.content: Well, there is no doubt about it that "The Goonies" is definitely one of the movies that you think about when you think of the 1980s cinema. Why? Well, because the movie was and still is fun for all ages to sit down and watch. Plus it is a very memorable movie as well.The storyline in "The Goonies" is something that appeals to adults and youngsters alike. There simply is something for just about everyone in the audience for this 1985 movie by writers Chris Columbus and Steven Spielberg, and director Richard Donner.I thoroughly enjoyed the adventure back in the mid-1980s, and I just sat down to watch the movie again in 2020 with my 10 year old son, and the movie was every bit as exciting, adventurous and entertaining now as it was back in the day. So you can definitely say that "The Goonies" is a timeless movie.And having grown up with movies, it definitely is a fun experience and a blast to watch a young cast in "The Goonies" that includes the likes of Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Corey Feldman, Martha Plimpton, Robert Davi, Joe Pantoliano and Anne Ramsey to mention but the most recognizable of faces and names."The Goonies" definitely have that "Indiana Jones" feel to it, and that is most certainly something that I enjoyed back in the mid-1980s watching "The Goonies" and being about 10 years old then. And the adventure in the movie is, again, something that has an appeal to children and adults alike.If you have never seen "The Goonies", then you most certainly should take the time to do so, if you get the opportunity. This is a classic mid-1980s movie. My rating of "The Goonies" is a six out of ten stars.

reviews.review_title: A Fanstastic, Funny And Entertaining Classic
reviews.content: The Goonies is one of those classics that you could re watch lots of times and you would still enjoy it as much as the first time.It tells the story of a group of kids who found a map with an X in it, so they decided to go across their town to look for the pirate treasure they think it's hiding somewhere near them, but they have to escape from the Fartelli Brothers who also want that treasure for themselves. The story is fantastic and is like a teen Indiana Jones adventure movie. The cast is perfect. From Sean Astin's Mikey to Josh Brolin's Brand, all the kids are fantastic in the movie, and they really act like kids, screaming one over the other, insulting each other, doing stupid things and that's a really great thing.The action and the adventure moments of the movie are fantastic. It's just pure fun and entertainment and it sure has some of the best moments of this kind of movies (I specially like the part in the ship and the parts where they're trying to avoid the "booty traps"). The score by David Gruisin does no other thing than increase the fun and adventure of the movie.I would recommend you this movie if you're an adventure-action lover, specially if the movie is set in the 80's.

I've watched this movie so many times over the years because it's just plain fun. Some of the stuff is a little dated at this pint, but most of the movie holds up really well because of the chemistry between the kids, the fun/exciting story, and the action. I still try to watch it at least once every year.
With all the acidic metoo vomit destroying the movies these days thank god we can fall back on the timeless classics like this it's just a joy to watch

'The Goonies' is one of those films that everybody has seen at least once in their lifetime and is something of a guilty pleasure for many. It's a rarity in that, although it's a kids film through and through, it goes down just as well (if not better) with adults.As someone who was born after 'The Goonies' was released, I don't have the same fond memories of this film as others who grew up with it do. For me, it's an imaginative and enjoyable family adventure, but not the 'classic' that it is to others. 'The Goonies' has some great individual moments and scenes but as a whole, I think there are better kids adventure films out there.

reviews.review_title: I wish I hadn't watched it!!
reviews.content: This movie is one of the worst I've ever watched!  About every other sentence had either swearing, using God's name in vain, jokes insinuating something bad, or disrespect to each other. The basic plot by itself was not bad; the underground treasure-hunt was an interesting idea, but I advise everyone that it is not worth watching, and it should definitely not be rated PG or labeled a "Family" movie!  I didn't feel like smiling at all throughout the whole thing, and I'm ashamed to say that I watched it all!

reviews.review_title: What is not to like about this film?
reviews.content: I grew up in the 80's.  I feel that it is a generation of films that'sa little more pure than what we have today.  There is a little more innocence in films like Raiders and Ghostbusters and Rambo and Back to the Future. But I guess if you were born in the 40's you would feel the same way about films in the 50's.  It's all a matter of perspective.  But watching a film like the Goonies brings me back to a time when my summers were spent not worrying about highschool, because I wasn't even there yet.  But we spent time going to the movies, "sad risking", riding our bikes and playing tag at the park.  It was a different time and a different feel.  And watching the Goonies brings me back to that time.  A time when friendship was different. Because when you hit a certain age, you have friends, but not the same way that you did when you were twelve or thirteen.  When we were that young, we all had friends like the Goonies or like the guys in Stand By Me.  And in a way, this film reminds me of Stand By Me.  They deal with different issues but they both have friendship at the core of the film.  And that is one of the reasons that makes it so enjoyable.  The Goonies is blessed with an all star production team.  From the direction of a pre-Lethal Weapon and post Superman, we have Richard Donner.  The producers are the Amblin team of Spielberg, Kennedy and Marshall and then you have the writing of Spielberg and Columbus ( Home Alone, Mrs. Doubtfire ).  With a team like this, you know you are in for a good time.  But what really makes this work in front of the camera is the great young actors of the 80's.  My favourites are Corey Feldman as Mouth and of course Chunk. Who can forget when he gets caught by the Fratelli's and he has to tell them "everything".  So he proceeds to gain their liking by telling them that he has pushed his sister down the stairs and blamed the dog and then making fake puke and dumping it over the balcony at the theater.  It is a very funny sequence.  Indiana Jones' Key Huy Quan is also priceless as Data, a James bond wannabe.  The cast of young greats really makes the picture.  The adventure the Goonies goes on is great for an audiene that enjoys an Indiana Jones adventure, and seeing that would be almost everyone, there are very few people that won't enjoy this film, although to be fair I think if you are under the age of 16 you will like it that much more.I have nothing bad to say about The Goonies.  It is funny, action packed, and has a lot to say about friendship.  And if you are my age, it brings you back to a time when life wasn't so convoluted and strange.  It brings you back to a time when going on an adventure that the Goonies go on would have been fathomable for you and your friends.  So how can you not like a movie like this?

Goonies is one of most iconic 80s childhood films to which many kids grow up watching it,this film mostly works based on nostalgia and cast that were really good which can be surprising since they were children,and we know how awful kids actors can be bad in films but here they were great in every scene,there are some noticable moments in which film doesnt hold up anymore by that i mean some writing and dialogue and villains were to cartoonish to be taken seriously or to pose a threat to our crew,goonies is one of best kid based film of all times and i think that many generations after us will enjoy watching this film and loving it

Not only was The Goonies a brilliantly written, directed, and acted movie, but it was also so much FUN! The adventures of these kids through the underground world, while being chased by the despicable villains known as the Fratellis, are fascinating to watch-movies.ga . The Goonies is a great cinematic experience. It has everything that anyone who was ever a kid could ever want. Even the elaborate sets are very convincing.

I watched this so many times as a kid.It's a fantastic older kid / teen adventure movie. Hard to find one like it made now. My kids have watched it over and overGoonies
Never say die!

reviews.review_title: Certainly NOT the greatest movie ever made...
reviews.content: Call me a cynic. Not only do I not like this film, but I am amazed at how many people here seem to love it so deeply. I did not see this movie as a child, so I don't have the same exaggerated emotional attachment to it as some. Still, I found it silly, overdone and incredibly annoying. Every one of the forced-cutesy kids in the movie (thanks, Mr. Spielberg!) needs a good throttling. The fat kid is the constant butt of cliched, mean-spirited joking. I have no idea what the Asian kid is saying anywhere in the film. Corey Feldman is obnoxious and, oh.. just happens to be able to translate Spanish and treasure maps and anything else when need be. Uh huh.The plot is absurd: are we really supposed to believe the kids could so easily track down a 400-year-old treasure that everyone else has overlooked? Would a group of professional counterfeiters run off and leave evidence of their crime in plain sight, knowing that a group of kids is nosing around? I don't think so.This lame movie is par for the course for Chris Columbus (Mrs. Doubtfire, Bicentennial Man) and one of Spielberg's weaker efforts (right up there with Hook, which suffers from many of the same problems as this film). There are some great films for kids out there. This isn't one of them.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films from my childhood
reviews.content: This is one of those few movies from my childhood that still brings a smile to my face. It's an essential adventure flick, filled to the brim with comedy and thrills. No matter how many times you go back to revisit it, the entertainment value is never exhausted.One of my favorite aspects of this film is how real the kids seem. They curse and try to act more adult than they actually are, just as most preteens are wont to do.Anyways, this is an awesome movie. Even though it's dated in some ways (but then again, every movie that ever has been and will be made is going to be dated, even our fancy CG-saturated blockbusters), it holds up very well. Show the kids or treat yourself.

I tried, I really did - but I didn't really like this. There are just far too many screeching, cacophonous, kids all talking over each other and after about twenty minutes I'd had about enough. It does get marginally better though, as these brats discover an ancient treasure map and have to compete with the menacing "Mama Fratelli" (Anne Ramsey) for the spoils. Robert Davi ("Jake") provides an additional slice of menace that could've been more effective had he been able to reduce the number of urchins a bit more effectively (indeed, a well placed rapier thrust could have belatedly rewarded us for the annoyance of "Short Round" from last year's "Temple of Doom"!). Sadly, their number is maintained to annoy and frustrate the much more capable grown ups throughout this increasingly predicable and slap-stick two-hour comedy drama. It has all the hallmarks of a Spielberg production and Richard Donner, to be fair, does up the ante as more action and less chatter starts to creep into the second half. The special effects are also quite effective and there is the odd comedy reference for those adults amongst us, but I just didn't get why this is so highly rated. It reminded me a little of the old-style Disney "Witch Mountain" films - but I think this is likely a film that will induce fond memories of childhood for those who still appreciate it now, I don't have those and so I didn't.

So I was about 15 when this thing came out. I never saw it, but over the years have heard good things and fond memories related to it. I decided to give it a shot - I tend to like these kid-venture movies from the 80s.Right away the red flags started popping up. Music by Danny Elfman. Oh no. That annoying staccato-strings and the cello trills splashed all over the place when something's supposed to be cutesy-funny. Oh the cringing right from the get go.That unbelievably annoying Asian kid from Indiana Jones (Mr Jones! Mr. Jones!). Oh no. Oh no.Back to the cutesy-funny. That's all this movie is - attempts at this type of entertainment that just fall flat.I could go on, but man I just hated this film. It was the Spielberg cutesy era that started with E.T., although E.T. was WAY better than this Goonies garbage. And why are they called The Goonies, anyway??
I had high hopes as everyone raves about this film. The plausibility of some of the action and characters was so ridiculous found myself cringing, not laughing. I have no clue why it's so popular.

reviews.review_title: One of the most iconic films of the past
reviews.content: Entertaining, creative, and adventurous. A movie that never fails to put a smile on your face is The Goonies. The film takes no time to lead you on an amazing adventure with a crew of extremely likable characters. This is one of the most re-watchable movies in film history.

reviews.review_title: I can like a lot of kinds of movies, but not this one
reviews.content: I have a pretty wide range of movies that I can enjoy. Based on how 'Goonies' has maintained some level of popularity over the years, I expected more of it. I couldn't even watch it all the way through. You can't enjoy a movie if you don't like at least some of the characters, and I found everyone in this movie unlikable if not downright annoying. Corey Feldman has never been a favorite of mine and I don't think anyone in this film had much of a future in acting save for Sean Astin, whose portrayal of 'Rudy' (in the movie of that name) I really like. His character here, ehh. And the only thing I like about Corey Feldman is that he had the courage to step up and expose the sexual abuse of young boys in Hollywood's film industry. For that, I applaud him, but that's not this movie. All the 'kid' movie characters he played reminded me of kids I actually knew back when, and didn't like then either.I found the 'Truffle shuffle' to be embarrassingly stupid (a fat kid having to pull up his shirt and shake his belly? C'mon...) and Corey Feldman's "translations" into Spanish for the Hispanic cleaning lady were juvenile and stupid and not at all funny. I saw that coming before the first subtitles hit the screen for what he was actually saying in his 'translations'. Time after time I felt like I was being left out of whatever this movie was trying to do to be entertaining, as clearly it was aimed at least 20 IQ points lower than my own.I guess I've dwelt upon young Mr. Feldman a lot here, but I should point out that I blame the role(s) he has played, not the actor himself. (Save for that insane musical performance he and his band did once on TV.)I had saved this movie online to watch at my convenience, but I got halfway through it, stopped it and deleted it.

Although little is known today about this film, it seems that every time I see it seems better, a true masterpiece of cinema. This movie is a true 80's classic that everyone should watch at least once in their life, with a truly good story, full of good jokes, good special effects, good characters and an argument that grabs the story to the end and that will make you see the movie over and over again. Very good, highly recommend.

Fun, light "Indiana Jones" for kids is this story from Steven Spielberg, adapted to the screen by Chris Columbus. Stars up and coming actors of the time including Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Corey Feldman, Ke Huy Quan and Martha Plimpton. Also starred Joe Pantoliano and the wonderful Anne Ramsey.Richard Donner directs (why is anybody's guess) this journey into fantasy as a group of young kids stumble through caves and booby traps in search of legendary treasure. "The Goonies" has all the ingredients to thrill the younger ones, with scary villains, thrilling traps and an amiable cast. For adults: don't expect the greatest adventure film ever.Theme "Goonies 'R' Good Enough" came from Cindi Lauper. Remember her?Friday, February 20, 1998 - Video

I give this film a low score today of course but God knows I loved it when I was a kid and used to watch it over and over. The Goonies is one of the things I remember of the eighties. America was very much in vogue back then, unlike now. I think they had Reagen back then and it was a much nicer and less scary world. My brother and I used to think the Goonies was so cool and their adventures were the very adventures we used to dream of at that age, it was only healthy after all to dream of such things and maybe write about it in your school essays, you know discovering a pirate ship and all. Yes I used to get my kicks and good vibes from this kind of film.

As a kid, I saw this one at the theater.  As a kid it is a really fun and funny action ride.  A bunch of kids getting together find a map in the attic of one of the kids and they decide to see what they can find.  Meanwhile, some criminals are loose and they find out about the map as well later on as their hideout is the starting point.  A very good movie for kids, but it is just ok for adults, though it is a lot more watchable for adults than most of the kid oriented movies these days.  Though there are a few instances that may be to dark for the smaller tykes out there as there are a couple of dead bodies here and there.  Looking back at this movie, one thing is interesting.  When seeing this movie as a kid, it seemed like their adventure was really long and they were underground a bunch.  When I saw it later again, they really weren't in the underground chamber all that long. One thing though I would like to see is the octopus scene that was cut out of the movie, but the one kid refers to at the end (when the kid refers to it should have been cut out as well).

This is one of those 80's family films that probably gets talked about a lot, and I suppose rightly so, from writer Chris Columbus (Gremlins), producer and writer Steven Spielberg (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Back to the Future), and director Richard Donner (The Omen, Superman, Lethal Weapon). Basically the neighbourhood of "Goon Docks" in Astoria, Oregon is threatened by developers who want to buy the area for a golf course, unless enough money is raised to stop the construction, Michael 'Mikey' (The Lord of the Rings' Sean Astin) and his friends Lawrence 'Chunk' Cohen (Jeff Cohen), Clark 'Mouth' Devereaux (Stand by Me's Corey Feldman) and Richard 'Data' Wang (Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom's Jonathan Ke Quan) are hoping to find a way to stop it from happening. It is while rummaging through old stuff in the attic that Mikey finds what looks like the treasure map of the famous and legendary pirate One-Eyed Willie, he is sure that it leads to a hidden fortune, so he and his friends, who call themselves The Goonies, set out on a quest following this map in the hope of finding the valuable treasure to save the neighbourhood. Along the way though the Goonies get themselves in trouble getting too close to a family of fugitives, the Fratellis, the brothers Jake (Licence to Kill's Robert Davi) and Francis (Memento's Joe Pantoliano), Mama Fratelli (Throw Momma from the Train's Anne Ramsey), with Chunk ending up their hostage for a little while, however the hideous looking but much nicer member of the family, deformed brother Lotney 'Sloth' Fratelli (John Matuszak), helps him out. Mikey, Mouth and Data are eventually joined by Brand, as well as Andrea 'Andy' Carmichael (Kerri Green), and Stefanie 'Stef' Steinbrenner (Parenthood's Martha Plimpton), and they follow the map through a series of underground caverns, with many booby traps along the way to try and stop them in their tracks. They manage however to get through all the traps and reach the large pirate ship, getting on board Mikey is beaming to see the skeleton of One-Eyed Willie, the Fratellis try to steal the treasure for themselves, but with the help of Chunk and Sloth the Goonies manage to defeat the bad guys, and in the end they get a bunch of valuable jewels out of pocket in time before the signature for the construction is put down. Also starring Lupe Ontiveros as Rosalita, Mary Ellen Trainor as Mrs. Walsh, Keith Walker as Mr. Walsh, Charles McDaniel as Chunk's Father, Elaine Cohen McMahon as Chunk's Mother, Falling Down's Michael Paul Chan as Data's Father and Nick McLean as Mouth's Father. All the young leads are a likable bunch with their individual characteristics, Ramsey, Davi and Pantoliano are good exaggerated villains, the story is definitely inspired by the Raiders of the Lost Ark with all the effects and scenery to create a child friendly romp, an entertaining adventure. It was number 24 on The 100 Greatest Family Films. Good!

reviews.review_title: Sorry folks nostalgia only goes so far...not a family night movie
reviews.content: I loved this movie as a kid, I remember talking about it for weeks on end back in the day, so I excitedly (I had not seen the movie in over 20 years) took my kids to see it at an actual showing. My kids immediately picked up on the cussing, (I did not remember cussing, but the movie has a lot of cuss words for "family entertainment"). I myself was shocked by the 2 dimensional stereotypes, obese kid, smart Asian kid, rich jerk kid, obnoxious kid etc. (and I thought politically correct characters are badly written), and the discovery that the humor was sophomoric (dare I say baseless). Even with all that, the movie was still acceptable, until my kids asked to leave, stating they would rather rewatch National Treasure, because the movie was "boring" (I must admit the pacing was glacier) and the dialog was "hard to follow" (everyone screams over each other). Anyway although I will always have fond memories of this film, I'm now way to old to actually enjoy it, and my kids have no interest in seeing it again.

reviews.review_title: Being born in 1996... I just have to say.
reviews.content: My parents grew up in the 80s and this was our family movie that I watched as a kid. I had this as one of our first dvds for our mini van growing up. This is such amazing nostalgia even for me being 25 now. As a kid, I thought it was brilliant. And even seeing it now, this will remain one of my favorite 80s movies. If you hate this film, you might be cuckoo.

Why did I wait so long before watching this movie? If I had seen this movie as a kid my imagination would have gone wild. When I was younger, I was always into the whole Treasure Hunting thing, always making clues and hiding them and having other's find them. The Goonies is basically a treasure hunt, and it's a damn good one too. I watched this mostly just because people were saying how great it was, and how it was one of the movies that inspired one of my favorite films from last year "Super 8." Well before I praise this movie, first let me say a few things that bothered me.The character of Chunk, the fat kid, doesn't go in the caves with the rest of the group, and in the last act, we barely see him. Which is a shame. Also some parts seemed a little too adult, I could handle the skeletons, but I can't really see why they put in the scene with the statue's genitals falling off. Also Data's accent got annoying at times, he sounds like Short Round from "Temple of Doom." But this movie really put a smile on my face, it's a classic adventure movie about finding a treasure. Like I said, I loved that stuff when I was younger, so this really brought a nostalgia feeling. The characters are great, sure they all fit into a stereotype: fat, Asian, cool, leader, but they all are so funny and likable. I like that they have both kids and teenagers on this journey. That way more people can relate. The villains are great, and the film had me laughing tons of times. I could say more, but I assume most of you have seen this film, and if you haven't, go watch it.The Goonies isn't quite as good as E.T., Close Encounters, or Super 8, but it's still a fun, nostalgic, and very funny ride. I will be buying this as soon as I can and it will go right on my shelf along with those other three.
This is a great film whether it's all the family or just watching on your own. Excellent fun.

The goonies are The emporium of The 80s about a group of kids finding a treasure map and setting off on an exciting adventure. It's a classic in its own right that everyone has seen at least once and been referenced multiple times in pop culture.What makes this a timeless master piece is the themes about friendship, class structures and family. Brent taking care of his brother, willing to risk his life and watch out for him. His friends all have a skill or an ability that proves useful and support each other through the lumberous made. The poor are harassed by the rich and need to stop their houses being torn down for a golf field and the pirates robbing from the rich to give to the poor like robin good.Steven Spisburge adds his touch with the beautiful music, enchanting characters and delicately put together plot keeping you entertained no matter what age you reach. So many jokes you'll catch like the officer saying Lawerence remember the time you said green creatures were taking over the town (Gremlins) or when he puked at the theater causing everyone to (stand by me). The jokes are humorous and have you rolling on the floor.Join Mikey, the boonies and the Fratellis on this wild adventure full of "booby traps, that's what I said."

The Goonies is one of the most iconic movies of the 80's and it's that way for a reason, number one the movie is fantastic and very original, the acting is pretty great for it to mostly be kids and all of which is one of their first movies.The original score and the Cyndi Lauper song The Goonies R Good Enough fits right in to the totally 80's classic movie and makes at least me love it even more.I would give this a huge 10 for the original plot, good acting, and overall a great time.

The stage curtains open ...I'm always a little apprehensive in reviewing such good movies, like this one, because I'm afraid my reviews won't do them justice. Such is the case with "The Goonies", this classic film from 1985 - which was such an integral part of my teenage years growing up.The story starts out with a tight group of friends, who call themselves the Goonies, spending what is to be their last Saturday together - since they are all about to lose their homes due to foreclosures and have to move to different towns and cities. They want to go out with a bang, so they decide to follow a map they found among some pirate relics in an attic, leading to the hidden treasure of One-Eyed Willy, the greatest pirate of his time. Along the way, they come across the secret hideout of the Fratelli's - a notorious gang on the run from the law. With the Fratelli's on their tail, they endure exciting dangers in tunnels underground while learning the value of friendship, reliance and loss as they try to save their homes and way of life.This movie carries with it some very strong sentimental attachments for me, as I was the same age as most of the Goonies were when the film first came out.. The characters almost became like friends to me: Mikey, Brand, Chunk, Mouth, Data, Andy, Stef ... and even Sloth. With names like those, you know it has to be a fun movie.I can't give this film any higher rating or recommend. Yes, you have to suspend disbelief and just let yourself be entertained. It is a fantasy, yet extremely funny - and it still holds up well even today. I watch it at least once a year, sometimes more, and I can quote the entire movie - line for line (but don't worry, if you were ever to watch this movie with me, I wouldn't actually do that since I know how annoying it can be). This is a classic! One of the best of its kind.

Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Corey Feldman, Jeff Cohen, Jonathan Kuan, Kerri Green, Martha Plimpton, John Matuszak, Anne Ramsey, Joe Pantoliano and Robert Davi star in Richard Donner's 1985 adventure. This takes place in Astoria, Oregon and begins with a jail breakout with 3 criminals, Jake Fratelli (Davi), his brother, Francis (Pantoliano) and their mama (Ramsey). Soon, we meet young kid, Mike Walsh (Astin) who lives with his brother, Brand (Brolin) and they're getting ready to move from their home taken over by a rich snob. Mike's pals, Mouth (Feldman), Data (Kuan) and Chunk (Cohen) come to visit and they find an old treasure map. They decide to have one last adventure hunting for treasure found by famous pirate, one-eyed Willie, but become trailed by the Fratelli's. The late, Matuszak plays Jake and Francis' deformed brother, Sloth who befriends Chunk, Green (Summer Rental) plays Andy, a girl Brand gets close with and Plimpton (The River Rat) plays her friend, Stef who join Mikey and the others on their quest. I've liked this 80's classic since I was a kid. It's got a great cast and excellent score by Dave Grusin. I recommend this.

'The Goonies' is more than anything else a hysterical movie; almost every character seems to be screaming most of the time. And quite a few characters are pretty annoying even beyond that, like Chunk (didn't he look like Bette Midler's grandson?) and his obsession with food, Mikey (Sean Astin? Really? I hadn't recognized him) and his ability to be utterly corny to the point one would call a doctor, or Mouth, who is just plain annoying. The plot itself is like Indiana Jones for kids, without the traveling, plus a dysfunctional Italian crime family.Nearing the end, things got better, with the dazzling water slide and that terrific underground set with the pirate ship (though that town and its surroundings were great to look at as well). One character who was over the top also, but still has my sympathy, is Sloth. Mother Fratelli, by Anne Ramsey, was quite 'lovable', too. All in all, a kid's film that is just about doable if you can take all hysteria, though I'd expected to feel more sentimental than I do.6 out of 10.

The 80's was a great time for those who were alive. The music and the movies of this period were incredible. Not to mention we had Ronald Regan as president and pro wrestling was hitting a fever pitch. What a wonderful time to be alive!The Goonies stands the test of time as not only one of the best movies from that period, but perhaps the greatest kid's movie today. If you grew up in the 80's and you are one of maybe 5 people from the United States who have not seen this movie, then due yourself a favor and watch it. You have a quirky, ragtag group of friends that discover a secret treasure map in the attic and embark on one last adventure before their town gets taken over by some corporate big shot and they have to go to separate schools.The emotion this film captures, especially in kids that maybe had to leave friends they grew up with because they were forced to move, is touching. The laughs are plentiful and if you knew a fat kid when you were growing up in the 80's, you likely tried to make them do the "truffle shuffle". I also had my daughter for the longest time thinking that the guy who played Sloth looked like that in real life. It was great.In honor of Sloth, if you haven't seen this movie, then allow me to say "Hey you guyyyyyyyyyyyys", you need to see it!

reviews.review_title: Pure Fun from Start to Finish!
reviews.content: Certain films seem to evoke childhood memories and playfulness. It makes adults remember back to times when they were children and when they cared about things more important than what adults worry about. It seems that once humans reach a certain age they lose their childhood fantasies and immediately become adults; but "The Goonies" seems to bring some of that back, and tells us that instead of worrying about pointless things, we should worry about family, friends, and neighborhoods. Yes, neighborhoods. That's what "The Goonies" is about.You see, the story is about a small strand of houses, called "The Goon Docks," located off the ocean. But the houses are all going to be destroyed because none of the owners have enough money to keep them standing.And so a sad group of children, called "The Goonies," are depressed and...well...sad. Sean Astin (now seen as Samwise Gangee in "The Lord of the Rings") , Corey Feldman, and a bunch of others are determined to get enough money to keep their beloved homes. In the attic of Astin's home, they find an old treasure map detailing the route to the treasure of an old pirate. Many have tried to get the treasure. None have succeeded. And so the boys (and eventually, girls, of course), embark on a journey to find the treasure so they can keep the "Goon Docks."This film is like so many others from the eighties; "Gremlins" is a lot like it. The way the set decorations are, the way the special effects are...The end of the eighties really marked the fall of campy-looking sets; now we see tons of "realistic" sets that aren't nearly as fun depending on the genre of the film. Comedies like "The Goonies" not only have great sets, but also some great gags and great memories. It reminds one of when one was younger; the Goonies go on an adventure looking for treasure, and which one of us hasn't done that before? When hadn't we, as children, worried about things that meant so much to us (such as the Goonies' homes)?Yes, "The Goonies" may not be the greatest film to ever hit the streets, but it's pretty darn entertaining and a pretty nice ride.

reviews.review_title: Just Not My Type of a Family Film
reviews.content: I guess it is just me, because a lot of people like this movie. Whether because of nostalgia, Spielberg or something else, but the fact is a fact.Well, I have watched a lot of similar films, and I can count at least 15 in the family adventure genre better than this one. I just didn't find it funny nor that much adventurous. The characters were boring except for one but with too little screen time. As for the decoration and set - it was very good + the directing was expectedly well made, but the story is where the movie fails I believe :/Final Score: 4/10.

This was such a fun adventure when it first came out, but it hasn't aged well.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
The story of "buried treasure" has been told, and re-told, countless times. One of the absolute best (if not #1)
films on this is "Treasure island" (1934) with Wallace Berry and Jackie Cooper. The twist here is modern and
has a sub-plot of poetic justice to it.Unfortunately, the story is nice but it's full of cliches and characterizations, e.g. The fat kid is always hungry
and clumsy, the Asian kid is the genius, etc. Obviously there are no black people since Hollowood was and
remains a "white man's world."ACTING:
Quite good acting, and you can see the early talents from Sean Astin and Josh Brolin.ENTERTAINMENT:
Value here remains moderate to high depending on age and if it's your first viewingTEMPO:
Good, but as with so many of Spielberg's work, the pace becomes increasingly frenetic past the half way mark ...
building towards the obsession with the "great climax" ... oh well.CINEMATOGRAPHY:
OK in the beginning but becomes an obvious set of an indoor fun house (you have to be a wee one not to see)DIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: Donner was a TV director before this, and that formulaic method that all TV is based on is clearly present.His work is consistently good, but so full of predictable and safe cliches that the films lack creative nuance.Writers: This team represents the "Council of Tripe" who can churn out quality stories, but most of their work becomes
the same stories and messages with rotating sets and costumes.Is it a good film? Yes, and is especially fun the first time (watch with kids)Should you watch this once? YesRating: 7.8.

When The Goonies was first made the prospect must have been sky high, with a story by Steven Spielberg and him being the Executive Producer, having established director Richard Donner directing, famous for directing the first Superman movie, and had at the time, the young and upcoming Chris Columbus wrote the screenplay.The Goonies tells an simple adventure story where a group of friends are being forced out their neighbourhood because of land-developers wanting to turn their homes in a golf course. Micky (Sean Astin) the leader of the group finds a treasure map and an ancient doubloon leading to a legendary pirate ship underground. They have one day to find it before their homes are foreclosed. Whilst on the hunt for the treasure the Goonies run into the Fratellis, a family of Italian-American criminals. One of them has just escaped from the local jail, Jake (Robert Davi), and the family an abandoned restaurant to counterfeit money. They are not afraid to murder number and go on the chase of the Goonies who could risk their plans.To people who grew up in the 80s and 90s love this film. A number of my friends really like it, and I remember seeing it when I was in Primary School. It is a simply a fun film with action and adventure, with a message of friendship. All the friends have their own character traits, like Mikey as the leader and the most committed to the quest, Mouth (Corey Feldman) as an little trouble maker, Data (Jonathan Ke Quan) the inventor and Chunk (Jeff Cohen) an child who wants to avoid trouble. There is also a good sub-plot involving Mikey's older brother Brand (Josh Brolin) and Andy (Keri Green) who slowly form a relationship during the film. Richard Donner is a good set-pieces director, and he is old-fashioned (and that's a good thing). They is excellent set-designs with good old style action. He used traditional techniques and not things like the birth of CGI and blue screen. He focused on this story and characters. They is a decent screen, and the first did feel a little like Chris Columbus directional efforts towards the Home Alone films. I also the score of the film.The film is not perfect and I did not like the use of proficiency by young kids in this type of film.Still an enjoyable film.

I remember watching this as a kid, and being generally disappointed. I was just getting to the age when I had twigged that certain actors, or directors might mean a movie would be better than another.  And one of the names I had grasped was Steven Speilberg. The fact Richard Donner (I also like) actually directed it passed me by at the time, but I think I can put the finger on my disappointment:1. Star Wars and Raiders of the Lost Ark had already fundamentally upped my expectation of what movies could be. 2. Speilberg's Close Encounters, Raiders and ET had all been fantastic 3. I had heard of Gremlims and Jaws but was too young to see them (I know Spielberg didn't direct Gremlins); but heard they were also good (I have a different opinion of Gremlins now...) 4. I think I saw Back to the Future just before I saw Goonies, and I really liked that film - and credited it to Speilberg (again he didn't direct though!) 5. I hadn't heard of 1941... ;-)I was expecting either Fantasy or Sci-Fi, but what I got was a bunch of cardboard cut-out kids going on what appeared to me (as a child) a rather childish adventure (the fantastical element was fairly minimal).  I did like Mikey, I didn't like Mouth (is Corey Feldmans top lip paralysed? it gets on my nerves for no good reason...), I did like Data (hey! I was a kid!), but didn't like Chunk (too stereotypical even for a  kid): result, mixed.Did I like it? Yes, it had lots of good moments, but overall I felt disappointed that there wasn't more to it.Last time I saw it I was about 15 (on video), so my views may be much better now - especially in light of it's cult following, and a number of rave reviews on this board.  I am curious to see Sean Astin again (now he is even more famous); but I suspect that it will still be rather average.

This film still holds up after all these years.A group of misfit kids set out to find a pirate's buried treasure in order to save their homes from being turned into a golf course. What follows is like an Indiana Jones adventure for tween boys. To make matters worse they are being pursued by the criminal Fratelli family who also want the treasure.What will happen? Will the kids survive, find the treasure or meet their end at the hands of the Fratellis?This movie does not disappoint. Nostalgia for those that have seen it before. Fantastic Fun. Worth repeated viewings!

Non stops thrills from Richard Donner and his cast of young stars as they bring to life this adventure film that features Sean Astin as the leader of a pack of "goonies," on the hunt for buried treasure on an old pirate ship. On their journey, they also have to tackle a notorious family of thugs, led by the wonderful Anne Ramsey. It's a fun film for kids and adults alike and features the music of Cyndi Lauper.

Plot; With their neighborhood set for demolition to make way for a new golf course, a group of misfit kids set out on one last adventure and get far more than they bargained for.The Goonies is considered a classic by many of my fellow Gen-Xers, but even when I was a kid it never did much for me. By all rights it should've been right in my wheelhouse, but for whatever reason I just didn't feel that connection. Still, I tend to revisit it every five years or so, thinking that maybe those tumblers will finally kick into place. This time they did. Sorta.I'll never regard The Goonies the way I do E.T. or even Joe Dante's flawed Explorers, but this time around I did gain more of an appreciation for it. The kids are all very good here, giving energetic performances and carving out unique and memorable characters in the process. The adults also fare well, with the Fratelli clan (Robert Davi, Joe Pantoliano and Anne Ramsey) making for a fun and eclectic group of villains. It also looks great, from the cinematography to impressive sets like One Eyed Willy's pirate ship. I suppose the thing I enjoyed most was that for 2 hrs. it took me back to being 10 years old, where adventure always seemed just a BMX bike ride away.

One word... Amazing!!! There is no other great movie where Sean Astin wears braces and has asthma. Corey Feldman is a sheer smart guy and nothing beats it. Chunk by the far is the best character especially when he is asked to do the famous truffle shuffle in his loud Hawaiian shirt. This movie even when I am 80 will be one of my favorites of all time and I by then will have seen over 10,000 movies I am sure. It is also sweet to see Joe Pantiliano in a criminal character role before the days of The Sopranos as Ralph. Sloth by far is the coolest character when he and Chunk become best friends. The young actors in this movie with the exception of Astin and Feldman did not have much of acting careers. Goonies forever!!!

reviews.review_title: A fun revisit to an 80's kids classic
reviews.content: Reliving childhood films at times, rediscovers a familiar part of you forgotten!
The goonies it is a really good old movie. It is a classic. It has adventure, action and comedy.

reviews.review_title: Classic Adventure That You're Sure to Love
reviews.content: 'The Goonies' is a classic adventure film that our youth film critics absolutely loved. Here's Raven's video review http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kvpL7if8gGw and below is her written one. I remember watching it all the time when I was younger and I enjoy it as much now as I did back then.The cinematography is good because it shows the age of the film. I also think the visual aspects of the chain reactions leading up to the contraptions are cool. When I was little I traveled in the area where 'The Goonies' was filmed, which was pretty interesting to see.My favorite character is Data because he is very funny and all of his inventions are super helpful in the search to find one-eyed-Willy and his treasure. I think this movie is for ages 10 and up because there is some inappropriate language. However, I don't remember noticing any of that when I was younger and I recently watched with my little brother who is 7, and he didn't seem to notice either. I guess it really just depends on the maturity of each child.Overall, I give 'The Goonies' 4 out of 5 stars because it is very entertaining and it has a good story line.'The Goonie' is playing in August on HDnet movies on Kidscene. Review by Raven Devanney, age 14, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic

For a big budget Steven Spielberg production the initial setup frugally takes place within one house, getting to know each kid's quirks and then, in the same house but upstairs, the ragged clan way-too-easily find a treasure map and the adventure begins: with a bicycle ride occurring in the course of a Cyndi Lauper song as "The Goonies" (never sure why they're called that) find another house where they spend the rest of the film: only underground where there are several mazy levels. Tons of bickering chatter, gratuitous product placement, hijinks-action and toilet humor make this flick, which could be retitled THE GARBAGE PALE OUTSIDERS VISIT THE TEMPLE OF DOOM, more suited for teens than children. Three villainous yet goofy thugs provide filler as they thwart the Gonnie's quest: which, despite the grandiose musical score, is really just a lot of running around. But the main problem isn't the plot - treasure hunts are always intriguing - but the Goonies themselves: it's never really clear why they're outcasts... or from what exactly.

For a short time in my life, The Goonies was the greatest movie ever made. While I'm older and have different tastes, I have no problem sitting through it on television or whenever my friend wants to watch it. Unfortunately, "kiddie" films like this aren't made with this kind of passion anymore.Granted, Spy Kids may have reestablished this medium, but that film didn't have the dialogue and wit The Goonies possessed. Its hard to say something like this, but this film is definitely one of a kind.

This could also apply to the reunion of Spielberg, Columbus and Donner but i was thinking to those Goonies kids! I think i saw them on screen when i was 11 during Christmas 85. Then i didn't get it was the new production of the team behind the great Gremlins of the last year but it was again a wonderful time: Chunk was really funny, Mikey got inspiration and Andy was just jaw-breaking (i couldn't speak without blushing!) ! Now i see that this team features LOTR Sam, Indy and Stand by me buddies so the cream of 80s kids: Brolin and Logia are forever cool here... For me, this movie is just awesome because it offers the best afternoon of fun, thrills, adventures we can imagine: it's like a role-playing session with friends (except mine had no girls) and it's much better than animated movies! Those kids lived in a beautiful location, had great values for each other, their parents and this pirate trail is much intriguing than those of Caribean! This movie is so great that today nobody can do the same! The DVD is really stuffed with nice outtakes, commentaries and a short making-of! So forget super heroes, violence and guns, steamy eroticism and hollow animals and be ready for this big magical adventure!

reviews.review_title: The Cyndi Lauper Nostalgia Machine still rocks...
reviews.content: Before tonight, it had been roughly 7 years since my last viewing of "The Goonies" (from an era where I bore the nickname 'Sloth' among a select few)...and at first, I didn't really know what to think. The hyperactive exclamations of prepubescent Sean Astin ('Mikey'), Corey Feldman ('Mouth'), Jeff Cohen ('Chunk'), and Ke Huy Quan ('Data')--the 'Goonies' of the title--kind of grated on my nerves with their novice, kitchen-sink performances (even considering the usual excesses of child actors, this was pushing it). But just as I was beginning to think that, the movie kicked into gear and began its enthralling course--yes, even at 25 years of age, I can say without a hint of shame that I had a lot of fun with this kid-friendly "Temple of Doom." Our titular characters live in an overcast seaside community, set to be razed by greedy land developers looking to put up a golf course. While messing around with the antiques in Mikey's attic, our boys stumble across a 17th-century treasure map, and decide to embark on a quest to find the (implied) riches contained within. In their travels, they also run afoul of the slapstick quartet of 'Ma' Frattelli (Ann Ramsey) and her three sons (Robert Davi and "Memento"'s Joe Pantoliano), one of whom is a hideously deformed--but very humane--Charles Addams caricature. The Goonies also run into booby traps aplenty, and the story maintains a surprising amount of unpredictability, considering its target audience (while *mostly* a kid's movie, the material isn't inaccessible to older viewers).That being said, Steven Spielberg's story credit seems a bit dubious, especially when looking at "The Goonies" from a distance: he could have very well approached Warners with "'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,' only with kids instead of Harrison Ford!" and collected his check on the way out. Whereas Indy, Willie, and Short Round altruistically braved peril to save the children of an impoverished Indian village, we have the Goonies altruistically banding together to save their threatened community.Of course, this would be bothersome...if "The Goonies" wasn't so much damn fun. Like the endearing classic "Ghostbusters," "The Goonies" is a similar 1980s gem, with a sense of creativity, adventure, and humor (including some fine one-liners), with plenty of crossover appeal to individuals who claim to have 'outgrown' this sort of film. If the film is dated in any way, it's only in the Cyndi Lauper theme song (which is still a bitchin' tune) that gives "The Goonies" its adventurously fun, young-at-heart identity.

I was in my teens in the 80's. While of course I had heard of this film, I never actually got around to seeing it until now. Maybe I'm just too old now. I literally had to turn it off after about 30 minutes. The CONSTANT screaming overlapping dialogue became unbearable. If you like noise, check it out.

The Goonies is yet another 80s teen/youth targeted movie that will transcend its time for years to come. In fact, I had just gone to a free screening of The Goonies in the park and the audience was primarily people in their early and mid 20s. So it looks like the people who loved this movie as a kid will cherish even as they get older. I'm one of them. As one of the greatest adventure film, The Goonies were a group of kids out of the Oregon boonies (aka The Goondocks). The Walshes who's son, Mikey (Sean Astin), is the unofficial Goonies leader, knows that his folks need plenty of cash fast to cover the back taxes and save the Goondocks from the like of that sniveling Troy Perkins's father.Hanging around the house one afternoon and driven by the curiosity of what Mikey's father might do with all that cool junk in the attic, the boys come upon a great discovery: a map of One-Eyed Willy's (yes, there are obvious synonyms to be made from the name) "rich stuff." So The Goonies are on one last adventure!Only, the map leads them to a bunch of fugitive gangsters called The Fratelli's (a terrific cast of villains featuring Anne Ramsey as Mama Fratelli; Joe Pantoliano as Francis; Robert Davi as Jake; and the late John Matuszak as the large, deformed and loveable Sloth Fratelli). When one of the Goonies get's captured by the Fratelli's, it doesn't take them long to figure out that these kids are sniffing a trail of treasure, and the Fratelli's want to get to it first, no matter what.Aside from a great story and a great soundtrack (featuring 80s queen, Cindi Lauper in the soundtrack and music video for the song, 'Good Enough'), you have a priceless cast and film crew. Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Martha Plimpton, and Corey Feldman (to some extent) have surpassed their transition into adult roles, so they've been around quite a while. Nostalgic viewers should get a kick out of seeing them a squeaky voice little kids--except for the gorgeous Josh Brolin, who was already 17 at the time of the film's release. None of the kids are annoying as those cast in family films often tend to be (and with the exception of some of Sean Astin's dialogue, it is hardly corny). You have a good assortment of characters like fast-talking Mouth (Corey Feldman), braniac inventor (Data), and the hyperactive fat kid (who may be the most well known character in the film and turned Jeff Cohen into a cult star, despite his not doing much in movies afterwards).
And of course, it is especially helped by filmmakers who always work well with family film material and young casts and scripts (like Speilberg with E.T.; and Chris Columbus with Home Alone and the Harry Potter movies), especially when it comes to the adventure genre. This movie really has a lot going for it and gives a lot of laughs from beginning to end.
Kids will surely enjoy this great modern pirate adventure! If you're a kid, it probably encourages you to seek out some Goonie adventure yourself, afterwards.

1980's adventure classic that brings pirate legend into 20th century Astoria, OR. A group of preteens stumble upon clues of a lost treasure nearby and decide to go on one last adventure before their homes are torn down to help expand a country club. Nostalgic but also timeless, offering enough originality to make it memorable while also sticking fairly close to the typical treasure hunt adventure. The character development gives off the feeling like there were so many adventures before and so many more to come but, behold, only one movie was ever made. Ramsey is always a terrific villainess, while Davi and Pantoliano have the right/intentionally-wrong chemistry as her two convict sons who are more interested in bickering and fighting for their mother's love than following the trail of the Goonies. Then we have the side-story of Chunk (Cohen) and Sloth (Matuszak), a duo that is worthy enough to have their own spin-off. Cyndi Lauper's song is also very fitting.***½ (out of four)
