The Goonies is a movie to watch on one of those cold rainy days.The Goonies are in trouble. The Goondocks is under a threat of being torn down buy a business tycoon who wants to build a resort on their property. The gang decide that they need to find a way to help Mikey and Brand's parents who can't come up with the money to save the house. They go into the attic to look around for something valuable and they come across an old treasure map that will lead to a treasure that used to belong to a pirate named One Eyed Willie.Along the way they run into the Fratelli's who are wanted for counterfeit. The Fratelli's try to go after the gang after they find Chunk who has gone to get help from the police. Chunk tells the Fratelli's that his friends went down the fireplace. Adventure follows.The Goonies have a wonderful cast. The late Anne Ramsey who plays Mama Fratelli qualifies as meanest mother ever. Even her own sons take a beating from her during the film. I love the little arguments she has between her and Mouth.My biggest problem with the film is that they don't decide to put the Octopus scene back in. You hear Data talk about it but we never see it. The people who own the film should re-release it with this great classic scene that I remember watching at a young age.Great classic 80's film.

This is underdog does good at its finest. You've got kids who are about to be kicked out by the "rich" people just so they can build a country club ("I hope they sink their balls and never get them out.") A little crush ("shame, shame, we know your name"). A comic relief, popular in the 80s "fat" kid ("do the truffle shuffle" "oh, c'mon" "do it!") Even an escaped criminal and family who are on the run from the cops, their vehicle recognized by Chunk because it has "bullet holes the size of matzo balls!" They collide in a humorous way, leading to the kids through a secret passage underground -- finding the "rich stuff", and Chunk unburdening his soul of his very worst behavior (his uncle's toupee as Moses' beard...the pushing of his sister down the stairs -- blamed it on the dog --, and the "worst": taking a bottle of fake puke to the movies and unleashing it from the balcony onto unsuspecting viewers below accompanied by retching sounds...) Follow along as they turn into pirates, friends and equals, then into kids again as they are-rescued finally on the beach. You can't beat this film for great one-liners ("I'm setting booty traps", "we could be downing the brew-skies, scoping out some babes, but NOOOO, someone had to go and fail their driver's license test", "Hit puree!", "Drug dealers wouldn't be caught dead in those polyester rags!"...) It's a must-see for anyone who enjoys a good adventure, especially those who root for the underdog and like to see the antagonists squirm and get it in the end.

Yeah, here I have to face one particular phenomenon. The Goonies is said to be a very famous and important movie, almost as good as Stand By Me (as far as I've heard and as some folks state). However, I didn't actually like it that much. I mean, it was okay; I didn't loathe it or so, but it was never something special for me. Never. The actors are doing a nice job, you can't complain about that, and the story itself isn't even boring nor weak. What I didn't like was the odd malformed guy. I did neither like his character nor his physical appearance. He's so dumb, in my eyes. So, what do I make of The Goonies? It's oversubscribed and unrealistic, the characters are unidimensional and the plot is witty but surreal. However, it has some good and entertaining bits. Ke Quan portrays an interesting character and delivers funny performances. Something you should see once, but nothing special.

reviews.review_title: The best kids film of the 80's
reviews.content: I'm properly writing this at least 20 years too late but for anyone who hasn't seen this movie it is the ultimate must see. The film has lots of comedy moments as well as the love shared between friends. The Goonies is a classic film that has stood the test of time, and no matter how old you get and how many times you have seen this film you never get sick of it. It has a treasure hunt, pirates, and villains. The cast are brilliant and the storyline fantastic. We all wanted to be Goonies and I personally still do, it should remain as one of the most successful 80's movies ever, a classic in its own right. And deserves its place as one of the top family movies.

reviews.review_title: One of the best adventure movies of the 80s
reviews.content: This movie will be enjoyed by the whole family. Nostalgic feeling... as a 90 kids we were fascinated by irate ship, gold, treasure and adventure and this movie just have it all. And most importantly the value of friendship and family.

reviews.review_title: I have a thing for chubby kids....
reviews.content: What can I say? This movie managed to give me the laughs, among other things....and every time I see the chubby kid, a certain Mr. Johnson begins packing up and moving all over.Chubby kids are fun and funny. Wouldn't you say?Yes, I would. By the way, check out Encino Man if you enjoyed this crap.

reviews.review_title: Cult favorite speaks to pre-tech generations
reviews.content: Based on the amount of comments here alone, I would have to say this film has become a cult favorite.  Once a film reaches that status any form of critique based on technical or artistic achievement becomes meaningless. Perhaps the reason this film strikes a chord is that it spoke to a generation which still hadn't been polluted completely by video and computers.  Videos were still pretty new and most households did not have a VCR.  AOL was just three letters in the alphabet.  Kids still had the opportunity and time to explore and use their imagination.  In this respect the film speaks to all childhoods up through the 1980's and can be enjoyed by all generations up to that era.  Of course, today's children can also enjoy the film but unfortunately they may not identify with this type of adventure.  However, it may inspire today's kids to go outside and use their brains and imagination instead of their remotes or keyboards and therefore giving this film more strength than it had the first time around. Incidently, during the eighties Mr. Speilberg enjoyed placing Disney icons in his films (try looking for them in E.T., Poltergeist, the Indy films, 1942, etc...)  In this film, his production crew copied the set pieces of the Disneyland ride Pirates of the Caribbean for the Pirate Ship/Treasure Cave scene.  In an era when movies are turned into rides (especially Speilberg movies like Jurassic Park, Back to the Future, etc...) it's neat to see a ride turn into a movie!

Tonight's movie review is in memory of the great Richard Donner the man who was behind the awesomeness Lethal Weapon series, Scrooged, Conspiracy Theory and the timeless movie Superman. Since this review is paying tribute, tonight's movie review will be children epic adventure The Goonies (1985). Believe it or not this is my first time watching this film this past week and since then I have gone back and forth to question why this particular flick has influenced so many shows and movies including Stranger Things.The story to me is straightforward, what would a bunch of bored kids get up to on a rainy day? Well, in this case, they settled on an adventure to find hidden pirate treasure whilst evading a bickering family of Italian mobsters known as the Fratelli's. The kids are from a blue-collar "Goon Docks" district of Astoria, Oregon and a bunch of them are trying to figure out how to save their homes from demolition. When the kids find a map written in Spanish which will lead to pirate treasure, they use the motto of "our time" and go onto an epic underground cave adventure. The treasure belongs to the infamous pirate, One Eyed Willy.The film itself starts with a Jolly Roger symbol then a jailbreak and a car chase which has a throwback to the 1930s and 1940s slap stick chasing where the homage is the Spanish housemaid in the middle of the road of a car chase. We see heaps of 60s to 80s throwbacks including the iconic Prince's Purple Rain printed t-shirt worn by 80s child actor Corey Haim and the James Bond theme played while the character Data uses his gadgets to swing from house to house. All this is good and all but there are some mirky weird remarks including the statue reference - why?? And the supposedly funny translation from English to Spanish scene - again not so childlike for a kid's movie. There is one thing I have noticed in the film, the lack of diverse characters. And this isn't getting woke or anything, it was just weird only seeing every specific stereotype except for one diverse family.The movie itself is okay and has some cool parts including the cave waterslide part - any kids true dream to get on that slide and fly mid-air into a pool of water in the end. The scene where the Andy has to play the correct notes on a a skeleton style organ was cool as. There are some coming of age scenes including the pash between Andy and Mikey and Andy and the older brother Brand. All the kids are great and do an awesome part in the film. The scene stealer to me is Chunk, our typical American kid who loves to eat and loves action and is a klutz. Plus, his interrogation and confession scenes were hilarious. The villains in this film are great and the one who really stole the show to me is Anne Ramsey, including her determined look chasing the kids in the cave to telling Corey's character Mouth whether he would like to eat tongue after he was ordering a few Italian dishes. Sean Astin as Mikey was cool and showed that it doesn't matter if you have an asthma pump when you are a kid, you can still achieve anything. And of course, you have you have Sloth, every child's hope that monster lookalikes are in fact good wholesome individuals. Plus, he was wearing a Superman t-shirt.This plus the Cyndi Lauper rack of "The Goonies 'r' Good Enough" were a good mix and yes I did watch the Cyndi Lauper clip and it was weird as much as the film where colourful pirates are chasing Cyndi with a sheik in the background is impatiently waiting to demolish a family home. Plus, you have the Hibachi scene!!Going back to the film we see retro kids riding their bikes with mates, seeing a teenager reading guns and ammo in the restroom and a first kiss. But to me this isn't a classic 80s kids film. At best a once or twice over, not a cult classic to me but it's still a good time, overall 7/10.

If this movie isn't on your top ten list of movies then obviously you haven't seen it yet. Out of all movies I have seen this movie had the biggest impact on me. It had everything you want in a movie without going overboard. I have never seen or rented a movie more than this one and everyone I have talked to about this movie agreed with me that it was one of the best films ever made because there was no other film like it. Sure it didn't have the greatest effects nor the greatest actors nor the greatest music but who says you need great anything to make a great movie. This is the most highly recommended movie. If you haven't seen this movie than you're missing out(either that or you're a rock). I enjoy it more and more each time I see it. I have never seen an adventure better than.....The Goonies. God, I am a huge fag.

Great, uneven masterpiece which resembles the work of Spielberg and Lucas. For example this movie reminds me a lot of the epic computer game "Maniac Mansion" because of the character of the kids and the weirdos in the old house. I grew up in the 1980s, and I still remember the scary scenes with the freak in the basement who eats chocolate. For some reason, it touched me a lot, that he was so hungry and starving. I just watched it again on DVD, and it is still pretty good, although somewhat uneven. I think it would have been even better if it had taken place in an old house or a forest or something, instead of the set-like tunnels it actually takes place in. However, the story and energy of the movie is so amazing that one cannot help like it. It is like other great 80s movies such as "Back to the Future" a great description of that particular generation.

Was really surprised at the low rating this movie shows.. this is a classic that many people around me still talk about years later. A group of kids coming together to help a friend that is losing his home. They go after a "legend treasure" that one of the boys find a treasure map to. It leads them to a group of criminals. A mom & 3 sons. One which is severely disfigured from birth. They have to escape from them to also figure out where this "one eyed Willie" hid his pirate ship with lots of treasure on it..It touches friendship, coming of age, falling in "puppy love", action, Drama, and loads of laughs & adventure!! Great movie for kids and adults of all ages!!

Every kids dream.... a treasure hunt.
All these comments stating that it was rated high because we were kids when we watched it.... sure we were. It's for kids. And always will be and enjoyed by the age group it was intended for.
Now.... just have to get my grandkids to sit still and watch it.

It's a great classic of it's time, a film that shows great kid camaraderie strewn beautifully across some incredible sets, resulting in a great ride indeed. You just gotta watch this incredible classic

5 kids find a treasure map in the attic and decide to pursue it hoping that it leads to treasure that has been stashed there for hundreds of years. However their innocent quest turns into a fight for survival as a prison-escapee and his brother and his mom also chase the treasure.This film starred: Sean Astin, Josh Brolin & Corey Feldman.The Goonies is a timeless-classic which was released in 1985, this film is funny, has a little bit of romance is is a great adventure and also has a bit of suspense. I like every character in The Goonies but my favourite has to be Mouth played by Corey Feldman he is just hilarious as is a great actor especially in this and the lost boys. Highly recommended.****/***** A near-perfect movie.

This film is suitable for children and their parents. Firstly, the plot is simple, it's something between "It" and "Home alone". Secondly, the cast is good, Josh Brolin is very young and plays typical older brother. Sean Astin plays person who leads others to treasure trough dangers. Sound very familiar, don't it? (he also plays Sam in LOTR).
So, it's good family film for evening.

The Goonies is a 1985 kids movie produced by Steven Spielbergo himself has Corey Feldman and the screenplay was written by Christopher Columbus who would go on to direct the first two Harry Potter films. Very high budget film of the time most likely. Very nicely shot like many films of this time period they spared no expense. I really liked the adventuresome storyline that shows a unrealistic/realistic trouble this group of kids called The Goonies get themselves into. There is the cute boy/girl aspect to the brother and the girlfriend. I love the Chinese kid Data and his totally wacked out gadget belt. This movie is not overrated in any sense. I would have loved to see this in the movie theater but it came out when I was a baby. I remember seeing ET in the theater and that's one of the films that really influenced me and my love for movies. It's films like ET and The Goonies that are just fun films that never die because there so good that we pass them on to the next generation.

I first saw 'The Goonies' when I was 10 years old and it instantly became my fave movie but I'm older and alot wiser now and would'net give it another glance.The story is about a group of adventures kids who discover a pirate map and set out on a fantasy treasure hunt to save there neighbourhood. This is the bottomless pit of the Spielberg genre, a silly tale which takes forever to get going and is acted by children who have not studied elocution. The trick effects when they come are OK, but it's a long annoying haul to that point.Mark: 4.5/10

reviews.review_title: Reminds me of everything I loved doing as a kid.
reviews.content: I'm giving this film a ten for reasons that are closer to my heart than a technical breakdown of cinematography, acting etc etc.I love movies; the older ones rather the than the newer. Because in my opinion, the older ones serve as reminders of how it used to be.I remember when I was that age, and I watch them on bikes and hanging out in their 'goonie' world. It is (excuse the oxymoron) almost exactly how I used to act with friends when the world was our own magical empire. We were never out to hurt anyone and we knew everyone in the neighbourhood and they knew us. The worst thing that could happen to us as kids was getting called in to supper when it got dark.I'm giving this film a ten, because of what it represents and how it does things. It reminds me how things used to be before I had to start being responsible for my life on a bigger scale.I think, though society has changed and kids are just not the same anymore (me being second generation in my late twenties), there is a goonie in everyone somewhere, and this film brings it out, and makes me laugh every time. It takes me back, excuse the cliché, to the wonder years.

I don't think anyone making movies now could make a movie to compare to this one.  They just don't make them like this anymore...They just couldn't!  All actors in this film give brilliant performance's.  This film is action packed.  Any young boy or girl for that matter should really watch this film if they are into adventures and treasure hunting...This film also has a great message of friends and family being the most important things in life.  The story is well played out, though I would love to see this intact...All cut scenes fully restored.  Oh, well I'm sure that won't happen.  Still the film is excellent...The relationships between the boys is very realistic, atleast for the time period...I don't think kids are like this today....This is a great escape from reality film that is a true gem!  Worth watching over and over again!10 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Loudy, a bit vulgar, and not very smart
reviews.content: This is one of the pearls defended by some of my friends with a similar age as "the movie to astonish your kids". But to be honest, I think the astonished was me. I saw the movie when I was a kid, but I didn't really remember too much (thanks god! I should have leaved it like that!). Now I regret to have seen it with my oldest. Just a bunch of kids screaming and swearing during a good part of the movie, fighting against time to discover a secret hidden in a very pathetic way, while a bunch of unattractive villains chase them to usual "they almost catched them" situations. Please, treat your kids as smart people, because they really are, and show them better adventure movies.

reviews.review_title: A Favorite Among My Siblings and I!
reviews.content: This movie is excellent! It is one of the best I've ever seen. I'm going to buy the d.v.d. very soon because it's a favorite among my siblings and I. It has everything in it, great acting, production, directing, photography, script, costumes set decoration, art direction, etc. I give this film 10/10 stars. Kudos to the cast, crew, and filmmakers. Two Thumbs Way Up!Spoilers Coming Up!My siblings and I have many favorite parts in this movie. These include: when Chunk spots the police chasing the Fratelli's and runs over to window and spills shake on himself. Also, the part when Chunk does the dance at the Walsh's house so they will let him in, when Jake Fratelli is too stupid to know what up means, and when they find the hidden treasures.I like how Chunk takes in Sloth at the end. He was being loving to someone who needed to be shown love. I like that. Great family film. Go Goonies!

That one quote rings most perfect to this movie. It doesn't matter how old it is, or how old you are watching this movie, it's timeless and ageless. This really brings back the magic of childhood with its sense of wonder. The Goonies themselves are all memorable in one way shape or form. Sean Astin definitely deserved an award for this role as the de facto leader of the group, but you've got to hand it to Jeff Cohen (Chunk) for his acting ability. In fact he steals half the show with his antics (long live the Truffle Shuffle!). I love the traps the group encounters as they're all creative, my personal favorite is the bone piano; you certainly don't see that everyday. But the ending is just great when you find out hope is restored when Rosalita finds the gems to save the homes that Mikey stashed in his bag. I end this review with this quote: "Hey you guys!"

The Goonies has got to be on my list of my all time favorite movies.  This in my opinion is one of Speilberg's greatest, because it is very entertaining and has a certain magical feel to it, like many of Speilberg's films.The characters are perfect and are all interesting.  My two favourites are without a doubt: Chunk and Sloth (especially together).

Considering what it tries to do and what it succeeds in doing, this could be one of the top ten movies of all time. I could show this movie to my audience (boys age 8-14) once a week forever and they would never tire of it. Say this about any other movie, I dare you. Everything about this film, from production values to special effects to sets to music to camera work to editing is A+ and deserves all the accolades it can get. Apparently I need to add lines about the characters to get over the ridiculous minimum requiring padding even if you've said all that needs to be said in a line or two. Sean Astin is cute, asthmatic and vulnerable and will grow up to be a good character actor, and type cast as a Hobbit because he is short. Josh Brolin, Martha Plimpton and Corey Feldman continued on to OK careers as older characters. In short, the whole is much, much more than the sum of its parts and is altogether a work of genius.After another 5 years my opinion has not changed one iota. This is a 10+ fivestar film for the ages; it appeals to kids of all ages and adults also because we (I'm 65) can at least identify with at least one of the weirdo goonies. Forever.

Haven't seen this till just recently, even though most people have seen this from childhood. I honestly regret it, it was such a fun movie. It centers around a group of little kids trying to find a pirate treasure using a map from the main kid's attic, which is a map of the city. They make their way to a cave within the mountains to get to the X, while being pursued by a group of bandits. Classic story that everybody knows and loves, and I haven't until now.Actors Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Corey Feldman, and others as kids, trying to find a pirate treasure, how can you go wrong. The characters are all unique in their own ways, and are fun to be around. Even the ones that are annoying, you learn to love. Chunk is a classic character, but when I saw him, it's like "oh, they're trying to make him annoyingly charming, oh brother he's just annoying", but by the end of the movie, he was one of my favorite characters, so funny. There's so much fantasy and excitement in the film, it just lifts you up and makes you want to experience it yourself.One thing i'll complain about is that writing in the first half of the film is just kids screaming at one another and not being able to hear what anybody is saying, it gets a bit thinner later one, but still. That's about it, other than that I enjoyed the film to no end. Such a good adventure that, while i'm sad to have missed out on as a kid, am so glad that I got to be a part of now.

Ahhh, the magic eighties. When everything were simple. And when there was Steven. With his E.T. and The Goonies...O.K. I'm guilty of being nostalgic. But hey, that was the decade they made best teen-movies and The Goonies certainly classify here. Adventurous action, humorous scenes (just remember the one, when one of the kid at the start of the movie translate stupidities to the spanish talking maid), great movie music (the opening music is definetly one of best I ever heard) and an "Indiana Jones" scenes. Combinig that you get the movie almost every kid like. Or an adult. It is fun to watch and it certainly bring memories back, when everybody wants to be a Goonie. All in all, it maybe not a classic such as Neverending story 1 or E.T., but it's close. Very close.That's why, a great8 out of 10

Sorry I didn't buy this and I'm happy in being minority.. Sometimes I do really question the American culture and especially when kids are involved. I expected this film to be something like Stand by me, but it turned out to be like Super 8 which was okay too. When you mix fantasy with reality, it should be handled very meticulously, there should be a fine line that not only separates fantasy and relaity both but also respects both the varieties. The Goonies literally fails here; when it began with some mild performances, I was put off by how the loud kids were, sure kids are meant to be loud and childish, but how come did they talk like how mature men do? How did they used the terminology of some aspects that was completely out of their thought process?Maybe this was the film made for kids and they liked it but I'm not sure if I should consider it as a coming of age film. No. It might have been a hit back when it released in 1985, but today it looks as if it just doesn't matter. I didn't care for most of the actors, except Josh Brolin cause he acted with sense. The guy who spoke fluent Spanish too was good enough. Everyone else didn't just catch my mind. I expected some real strong emotional bonding like the kids ahd in Stand By Me. Here what I saw was just simple mischiefs and trying to carry out abrupt laughter through them. I'd say 3 Idiots is a better film than this whuch at least has some message in it that can change lives. 4/10.

If I ever had to narrow my DVD collection down to ten, the Goonies would definitely be a keeper.  I first saw this one sixteen years ago and, as anyone from the era can tell you, it only gets better as you get older. Who knows what it is about this film?  I don't think it was inteneded as anything more than a good matinee time-killer, but when Spielberg and Donner set out to make this one with a cast of virtual unknowns, they created a true classic.  True, it's a cinematic mess, but a wildly entertaining, inventive, cinematic mass with a dose of good ole fashioned nostalgia.  I imagaine that if I had just now seen this movie for the first time, it probably wouldn't have had the same effect on me.  It does something that no other movie (with the exception of Back to the Future) has done for me. It takes me back to those rainy days, when I was a kid.  I still remember. You see, my house was the "kool-aid" house of the neighborhood and all my friends hung out there.  When the weather was too nasty for riding bikes or whatever, you could bet that the Goonies would be in our VCR and we would be kicked back with popcorn and sodas, laughing our asses off at Chunk doing the truffle-shuffle or the bumbling Fratelli brothers bickering and pulling guns on each other.Over the years, I've owned probably a half-dozen copies of this movie and I just got the DVD last August.  It was really cool to see the entire cast get-together for the audio/video commentary and see them arguing and laughing just like in the old days.  It's still a mystery to me why they never did a sequel.  With the popularity of this one, Hollywood would definitely have another Harry Potter on their hands.Although it may not have the same sentimental factor, I urge anyone who hasn't already seen this film to give it a try.  It's great for kids and who knows, maybe 8 year-olds who see this now will look back on it the way I do. Donner, If you're reading this, please round up the old cast, call up Spielburg and get to work on the Goonies 2.  We NEED it.

reviews.review_title: Still a very charismatic action adventure
reviews.content: Too much of a classic to be a bad movie. Even so many years later!

reviews.review_title: I don't understand why everyone loves this film?
reviews.content: I watched this film after it being recommended to me by lots of different people, and I'm sorry but I don't see the appeal at all. I went into the film with big expectations. I wanted to watch a funny, enjoyable and all round family film, but I finished it wondering why I spent my time on a lazy, boring and basically dumb movie. I don't understand the choice to have every kid in the film just try and shout over each other, through the screaming I could barely make out any of the dialogue and when it finally seemed to settle down, what I could make out of the script was that it was just lazy writing, everything was just too convenient. Everyone's entitled to their own opinion and mine is that the action and characters are just plainly implausible and the whole film is just a bore from start to finish. I hear the excuse of "it's a kids film" and to me, that just seems like a poor excuse for a film you think is infallible because it's a nostalgic movie and was one of you're favourites growing up however sometimes people don't want to accept the truth and yet the truth is that it's actually just a ridiculous and stupid 2 hour mess!!! I have a good friend who I rely on for film recommendations and she said to me "you've got to accept that it's an 80's kids film" and I do, it's just that Back to the Future was released in the same year, merely 2 weeks apart, with the same certificate, and to me there isn't a comparison between which film is better. Back to the future for me is a film which ages like fine wine, whereas Goonies, I hate to say it but it's aged as well as a PT cruiser.

I have loved THE GOONIES ever since I was a kid and I don't think I'll ever get tired of it. A young Sean Astin performs excellently as the group's pseudo-leader Mikey. Corey Feldman provides plenty of laughs as the mischievous Mouth (I loved the bit where he 'translates' Mikey's mother's instructions to the Spanish maid into Spanish). The rest of the group are colourful, with each one being made an individual. The late John Matuszak is great as the deformed Sloth who ultimately helps to save the day and the villainous Fratelli family are portrayed in a very funny light as well.The only really hateful villains are the country club crowd who want to tear down the Goonies' houses to build a golf course, which is why our group embark on their journey for buried treasure in the first place. The underground caverns and the various booby traps set by pirate One-Eyed Willy are very brilliantly done. There's also great music by Dave Grusin. I recommend THE GOONIES strongly. It's a great, fun movie.

On the UK video release of the Goonies, they edit out the subtitles saying that it's Mikey + Brand's father's sexual torture equipment in the drawers.This is something that should be put into the alternate versions of the film, rather than a review in its' own right. I can't, however, find the button to tell me where to submit this information.

reviews.review_title: Sort of a teenage version of Raiders of the Lost Ark
reviews.content: In 1981, director Steven Spielberg made an adventure movie called "Raiders of the Lost Ark". That film features one of the most popular action hero, Indiana Jones. In that film, Spielberg's tale was about a archaeologist, who tries to retrieve the Ark, which was stolen by the Nazis. The concept of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" is also used in the new adventure film called "The Goonies". The Goonies tells the story about a bunch of kids, who lives in Astoria, Oregon. They like to go on certain types of situations together, considering that they're all misfits. When one of the kids stumbles upon a treasure map in his own attic that belongs to an old pirate named One-Eyed Willie, the Goonies set off on their last adventure. The problem is that greedy real estate buyers want to foreclosure the house and the kids must save it before it is gone. Well, the Goonies runs into troubles on their own as well, Three bumbling bad guys are also chasing and going after the Goonies as they descent more and more underground. I thought the underground set design was impressive though I had some questions about the caves and one concerning a well but, nevertheless, convincing. The idea of the underground caves is probably set to be a kids' hideout of some sort. But, never mind about that. Anyway, the film gets better as the kids falls through all kinds of booby traps. The booby traps are sort of ripped right out of the Indiana Jones movies, specifically the first one and the second one. The ideas behind this movie gets even more better. An giant man named "Sloth", who has a grotesque, deformed looking face, joined the gang, and also several girls are added to the list of characters. There is a lot of fun in The Goonies. I admired its energy and its style. But, there are questions that I ask myself when watching The Goonies. Those questions weren't important as the movie. Basically, this is nothing more than a funny, exciting, thrilling teenage adventure story. One other thing that I didn't mention. Some of the young actors who played the Goonies, like Sean Astin and Josh Brolin were good as the roles they presented. And, also, I enjoyed the supporting characters as well. Anne Ramsey, who plays the mother of the two criminals who are chasing the kids in the underground caves is pretty good is this movie. She's convincing and intimidating as the supporting character. ★★★ 3 stars.

The Goonies is the pinnacle of 1980's Kid's movies - it tells the story of a group of misfit kids (called....  The Goonies) who embark on a adventure (old school style) to find the hidden treasure of One Eyed Willy (no that isn't supposed to be a rude name).  All the kids are fouled-mouth and they mess around with the Fratellis - some crooks on the run from the long hand of the law. This is one of my top 3 kids movies from the 1980s - it is totally cool - with the bracers wearing Mikey, the jock older brother Brand, the loser fat kid (Chunk), the gadget kid (Data), the wise guy joker (Mouth), the sweetheart of the jock (Andy) and her nerdish friend (Stef). The characters, the dodgy child acting, the action, the bad guys, the lines - it's all here. Probably people who didn't see this in their childhoods wouldn't appreciate it - but I do!

After all the raves at the time and the odd people that I've known over the years praising this film, I've finally watched it after 35 years.
Personally I found it boring.
It started off promising, but then it basically turned into 90 minutes of 11 year olds, running around in what looked like the inside of a theme park ride, screaming and shouting.

In a long list of classic kids' adventures, the Goonies has gotta be at the top of the list. The Goonies is the crème of the crop when it comes to 80's cult classics and the legacy is almost unmatched. The story is a simple pirate treasure hunt tale taking place in 1980's Oregon. But as the Goonies navigate their way to One-Eye Willy's treasure, their journey is full of heart and friendship. Not to mention a long list of iconic quotes and scenes. The Wishing Well scene alone can be quoted by every cultured swine between the "goonies never say die" line and the "it's our time down here" speech. With action, comedy, and emotion, this film is the perfect balance as all things should be after 35+ years providing nostalgia for multiple generations.Yeah.... So Samwise Gamgee plays Thanos's kid brother in this film. Pop culture icon, Sean Astin, and Josh Brolin lead the rest of the cast with Jeff Cohen, Corey Feldman, Ke Huy Quan, Kerri Green, & Martha Plimpton by their side. Cohen's performance as Chunk is legendary. And Plimpton as Stef is such a mood. My favorite thing about the cast is how well they are together in every scene. Their chemistry on screen allows all the kids to just be so present with every line and sequence. Comedic dialogue always hit and the emotional scenes made me believe they really were a close nit group of friends.No question that the Goonies became a staple image of the "oddball group of friends" and you can really see that in similar stories, like Strangers Things (even without Sean Astin in season 2). Firstly, the film perfectly captures the spirit of an innocent childhood adventure while also being a coming-of-age story. Paired with that, this is a pack of quirky outsiders that thrive when they're together. The Goonies, themselves, are insanely relatable. So we're emotionally attached to these kids as they begin they're exciting journey to find treasure. It's a simple and effective formula that just works.

reviews.review_title: Goonies and Gremlins never get old
reviews.content: I don't like making a comment No 2364 or more, so I keep commenting less popular movies.  But reading some recent comments I just want to add a few words.This movie passes the test of years very good.  I saw it few days ago for the first time, together with my teenage kids who watch South Park, Resident Evil and other action, horror, violent movies made last few years, that I never heard of (and don't want to).  But they were delighted watching Goonies.  My fifteen year old sun said "Now I'll have also something to recommend in school!".  And I like that the main characters are "real" kids.  Today so many movies show early years of movie heroes.  First it was in cartoons ("Young Tom&Jerry, then Bungs Bunny"), but later we have young Indiana Jones etc. It seems noone has imagination to make new kids characters, so I'm expecting to see young Schindler as a kid-hero of WWI, or young Rocky as sport star of his college.  Some scenes probably couldn't be made today, especially in "PG" movies, because US censors and movie-makers protect children (releasing South Park in the same time - "not for children" of course, so they get even more interested in it).  But this scenes make the characters much more real, and give the movie less sterile look as many recent movies have (unless they're made in France, Sweden or somewhere else in  Europe).And one remark that might be dropped out and swept away by the administrators, but I'll write it anyway.  I read a comment posted by DonFreidle.  It was a bit surprising, so I took time to read his comment list, and found out that he signs himself each time from different place or even continent (Europe, North or Latin America...) and his comments are sometimes distasteful, sometimes humiliating - all of that is his right if he feels it and it's his style; but these comments are often misleading (read e.g. what he wrote about Kubrick's 2001).  Suggestion: when you decide to watch some movie or not according to comments in IMDb, and find something like this (he is not the only one, of course!) read some of poster's other comments to understand him as the person and make a final decision only after that!  And, watch the Goonies, but not because I write it, but because so many others do it too!

reviews.review_title: The archetypal kids adventure movie that shaped the decade and the genre that would follow.
reviews.content:
The Goonies is a movie that's inevitably going to show up on most all lists dealing with films of the 80s. While it does include its fair share of references to a good bit of 80s culture, the biggest draw I found with the movie is in the story. By no means is this a claim to boast it as being the most original story, but the smaller decisions to use a younger cast, focus on a classic pirate storyline, and root it with such relatable dialogue and characters is where the magic happens. 
The Goonies thrives from the kids. The careful casting, writing, and direction that went into making each kid their own special character is what has propelled the movie for decades. The stoic nature of Mikey plays perfectly off the perfectly named Mouth. The inclusion of the gadget based Data gives the movie a nice geeky side, and the cherry on top is in the form of the scene stealing Chunk. Then while the movie makes the smart decision to maintain its focus on the kids, the short fray into the teenagers subplots provides an enjoyable draw for the adolescent age group as well. Parents of today can then turn around and reminisce on the adventurous joys that came with being a kid in the 80s.Unfortunately a common argument that plagues a certain amount of films of every decade, but can stick out at times here is the technical aging of The Goonies. The dialogue dubbing, outdated special effects, and cheesy one liners can be distracting at times. In addition, the teenage subplot while minimal feels very artificial and last minute. However, at the end of the day, The Goonies lighthearted, feel-good story, dialogue, and characters cement it in the Pantheon of 80's Classics!

reviews.review_title: One Of The Best Children's Movies Ever Made
reviews.content:
I was 18 years old when this movie came to theatres in 1985 and I loved it so much I went to see it at the theatre four times. That doesn't count the number of times I've seen it aired on television. But, what can you expect from a man like Stephen Spielberg ? He has a knack for bringing out the best in child actors. This is definitely one of the best children's movies of the 1980's, next to "E.T. The Extraterrestrial".
Lawrence 'Chunk' Cohen was the most hilarious kid I had ever seen at this time. He kept me laughing thru the movie as well as everyone else in the theatre. I don't think I  had ever laughed so hard in my life, especially when he did that belly shaking thing. What was it called ? The truffle shuffle ?
Anyway, this movie is well worth letting your kids see -- over and over and over again.

This movie is basically one of my all time favorites, because you can feel the adventure that they are going through. I love each character and story behind them. I've watched this movie religiously and still enjoy it at what age I am. I really don't find any bad things about this movie. The plot is great, the characters are lovable and enjoyable, the villains are great in every aspect.

The most creative part of the film is the repeated interludes between the magic land symbol of cave and the real world on the ground, which clearly indicates that this is a sewer exploration. The film sublimates the concept of "childhood fantasy" in the process of plot development and makes a heartfelt praise to the children's magic image ability and adventurous spirit. "above is their time, their world, below is our time, our world."

This film is awful. The acting is horrid, the story non-existent and the pacing glacial. The only positive aspect of this film is nostalgia, and in the cold, hard face or adulthood even that is stretched thinner than the stars' acting abilities.

Ah, one of those sweet childhood memories from the mid eighties. An excellent adventure that keeps you seated from the first scene to the very end. This movie includes a few teens from a boring town, a very old map, a Spanish boat, a dark cave filled with booby traps and countless skeletons. I liked One Eyed Willy -  although he didn't say a word. And what would a good movie be if the credits didn't include the name 'Steven Spielberg'? Right...Although I enjoyed "The Goonies", I must say that the whole thing is about 'finding a treasure', a subject that doesn't look too exciting. In fact, nothing interesting happens in the first twenty minutes of the movie. All the fun begins when our Goonies enter the cave. Unfortunately,when the Goonies find the secret entrance caves, traps and bones are the only things that pass your screen until the end.Must-see and must-have movie, which deserves a **** out of *****.

reviews.review_title: Kids movies don't get much better
reviews.content:
I must have seen this movie 15 times as a kid. It's one of those movies were everything just clicks. I remember thinking I actually was a goonie, and craved adventures like these kids went on. I haven't seen this movie for 10 years but I can still recall practically every scene, from the truffle shuffle, to Sloth's heroics, to the inspector gadget kids creations.
9/10 for kids.
This movie brings back so many memories of my childhood.  It's a fun little adventure that kids would love, and adults can still get into it.  One of the greatest things about the 80's.

Yes... to the past. And yes... from the past. Having seen this a couple of times in my childhood with my best friend on VHS and with chips and softdrinks, this really was a pleasant surprise on Amazon Prime.Watching this again in 2021, it truly stirred up some really good childhood memories. The friendships, sneaking away from home and all the rest that made my childhoodyears more bearable. The Goonies had so much good stuff in it, that it never got boring and was fun to watch every time.Looking at it now, it's still a good movie. Yes, outdated, but a solid story with a great cast and that "magical" Spielberg quality that is so recognisable. I loved watching it again!

If you were a kid in the 80's, you must have LOVED this film!!It's probably the best film I'd assossciate with my childhood. It's got everything you want - action, comedy, a little bit of romance, adventure, and it all revolves around young teenagers!God, I really wanted to be one of those guys - I'd like to think of myself as a Mouth type character, but the reality was, that I was Chunk type character. That's what's also so good about this film, you have all the stereotypical kids in this movie - from the fat stupid kid, to the brainy kid who is just a little bit too brainy!We all know the plot - or at least we should, and it's a good one too.The film has a nice appeal to it, me and some mates watched it very recently, and though it seems a little dated, it still is a lot of fun to watch. Now that we're older (all roughly 20/21) we get the subtle nuances of the jokes. I mean is it just me? or did I completely miss the sexual reference to 'One Eyed Willy'????!!!!!!!!! I'm soooo naive!!watch this film, re-visit your childhood and enjoy a great piece of the 80's.9/10

reviews.review_title: If this movie doesn't make you smile then I don't know what does.
reviews.content: Released in the summer of 1985, The Goonies is the film that I always bring up when I challenge one's coolness. Everyone is entitled to their opinion but what you need to know in order to appreciate this film is that it's purely and simply, a fun adventure film. While yes, the script isn't the most clever ever written, I think that Chris Columbus brings enough character development and well written action scenes along with a lot of heart that makes it a really well laid out screenplay.Steven Spielberg had been in the spotlight for 10 years at this point, thanks to the success of Jaws (1975), Close Encounters Of The Third Kind (1977), Raiders Of The Lost Ark (1981) and most especially, E.T. (1982), which was in its day the highest grossing film in history. All films are absolute perfection in my mind and show us why we go to the movies to begin with. Spielberg was now everywhere and not only the most powerful director in Hollywood but also the most powerful producer. By now, he was even showing his talent as a producer and it was one hit after another. With Poltergiest (1982), Gremlins (1984) and the mega hit Back To The Future (1985), Spielberg could do no wrong and proving that unlike most directors and producers, he clearly knows what the audience wants but also what works and what doesn't.Which brings me to The Goonies. Spielberg originally came up with the story but brought in Gremlins writer and future director Chris Columbus to write the screenplay. He then hired Richard Donner, best known for films like The Omen (1976) and Superman (1978), to direct the film. In my opinion, one of the things that makes this film work so well (besides the script and the actors) is Richard Donner's direction. He brings a sense of excitement and also, tension to the screen. From the very first scene involving a jailbreak, this is a director who knows how to make a movie I think, his camera work and directing of the actors is amazing, it gets you hooked into the story which I have to give credit to Donner. Sometimes I wonder if the movie would have been just as great if Spielberg directed the film himself and don't get me wrong, Spielberg is one of the best directors in my mind but Donner's approach is something to be acknowledged. I actually think it's his film in a way.So yes, I do consider this a cinema classic. It's a film that we can all connect with. I remember one review on IMDb pointing out how this film unifies us and I couldn't have said it any better. Anytime you say The Goonies, people know exactly what you're talking about and they always quote a line from the film. This is the true definition of a cinema classic in my mind, a film that is loved all over the world and it's not just a part of pop culture. I would place this movie up there with Citizen Kane or Casablaca as silly as that may sound to some. If you're a movie lover like me who loves to go to movies to feel uplifted or just have a good time, then this movie is for you.

reviews.review_title: Nostalgia for those who grew up in the 80's
reviews.content: Maybe those who didn't see this movie as a kid will not like it, but I have seen it countless times.  It's plain and pure fun all the way, taking things lightheartedly, but so what if it's a kiddie flick?  We are given some of the most memorable characters such as Chuck, Data (slick shoes anyone?), Mouth, and Mikey.  The villains, those infamous Fratellis, are a blast to watch.  Everything feels so 80's, much like the Breakfast Club or Mannequin. Not to mention Cyndi Lauper!  Goonies are good enough ... oh yeah.  Some people have to understand that when something struck a chord within a child, the experience will carry on until adulthood, and I guess that's the case for me, as well as for the many, many generations who grew up listening to Pet Shop Boys or Duran Duran.  Anyhow if you don't like it, your kids DEFINITELY will!!!

aahh, the fun of watching 80s movies is always a breath of fresh air! The Goonies is a film that I had fun watching every single time. I grew up listening to Mouth's big mouth, Mikey's (and his mother's) stubborn ways, Chunk's love for food and so much more.it's one of the best 80s film that i have watched... okay Ferris Bueller too, but this is one of my favorites that make me forget my troubles and just enjoy the show.i am a goonie! are you one?

i was 8 years of age, when my sister, who was then 17, introduced me to the goonies. I loved it as any normal child should. And from then on, every time it was shown on tv, which was a lot. I would watch it, i would cancel playing out with my friends to watch it. It was just so addictable. It's the perfect family film, with comedy and scares for both youngsters and adults. The characters are easily relatable and instantly memorable. The soundtrack dated but fitting to the movie. Its just fun all the way really. Extremely well directed by Donner, who manages to get great acting from the young stars. It's a classic slice of nostalgia. It's a shame that only one of the kid actors went on to greater things.

I liked this film as a kid. Good storyline, characters, humor, and action were all a part of The Goonies in my opinion. Honestly, this is the only decent film that Sean Astin and Corey Feldman were in to me. Also, this exposed Cyndi Lauper to me for the first time in my life. And now I like listening to her from time to time. The kicker here is that The Goonies 2 or whatever sequel has not happened yet. I am guessing that the past actors, writers, director, etc. are not enthusiastic enough to develop that reuniting project. Oh, well.

Too many implausibilities to make this enjoyable.  There were plenty of good quips and jokes, but not enough to overcome many inconsistencies and ridiculous assumptions required of the viewer.  Actually, not a bad story for those under 8 years old, BUT the potty humor is only suitable for those 15 and over.  Bad combination.Spielberg should remove his name from this mess.

The Goonies is another of my favorite movies of all time. Who hasn't watched this many times over the years? When I was growing up many friends wanted to go on adventures like the kids in this movie.Mikey, Mouth, Chunk, Data and Brand are the Goonies. They find a treasure map and all except Brand think it will lead to something. Something that will save their homes. They have to over come obstacles and booby traps as well as being chased by three dangerous criminals, the Fratellis. They enlist the help of Andy and Stef along the way. Another enlistee is an unlikely ally in Sloth, who is a Fratelli, but is mistreated because he is physically and mentally impaired.The Goonies first encounter the Fratellis at an old restaurant along the coast. The restaurant is the starting point for the treasure map. They decide to wait until the Fratellis leave to explore the restaurant. The Fratellis come back unexpectedly while the Goonies are in the basement. Their only way out is to go through a secret passage in the fireplace. Chunk is left behind because he got trapped in a freezer when they found a dead body. Chunk escapes the basement through a window but is later picked up at the side of the road by... the Fratellis.Meanwhile Mikey, Mouth, Data, Brand, Andy and Stef continue on with the treasure hunt. They come across several booby traps and the remains of a former treasure hunter. They find a key around the neck of Chester Copperpot, the dead treasure hunter, and then set off a booby trap that drops large boulders from high above that are meant to crush intruders.Next the Goonies find a well and they think for a split second that they have found the treasure. Unfortunately all they found was a wishing well. A suitor of Andy's, Troy, happens to toss a coin in the wishing well. The Goonies throw the coin back up and he offers to help them out of the well. Mikey talks the others into continue on the treasure hunt.Back at the restaurant the Fratellis question Chunk. After finding out that the tunnel in the fireplace really exists the Fratellis leave chunk tied up in the same room where Sloth is kept. Chunk and Sloth become friends. Sloth breaks free and helps Chunk to get free. Sloth hears his echo coming from the tunnel in the fire place and follows it, leaving Chunk no choice but to follow.While in the well the Goonies find another booby trap that nearly kills Data, but he saves himself by using his "pinchers of Hell". They climb down into another tunnel. Having decided to get a pitstop out of the way Andy decides that it is time to make a move on Brand. Brand sends Mikey to see what Andy wants and ends up getting kissed by Andy. Andy thinks it was Brand that she was kissing.The next obstacle is a log bridge over a raging river. Data is the last to cross and he sprays oil along the log to slow the Fratellis down. It works.The next booby trap the Goonies find is a piano made of bones with a skeleton as the a head piece. Andy has to play the notes on the back of the treasure map in order to help the rest of the Goonies to continue on their quest. If Andy fails to play the correct notes the floor will drop away and they will fall to their deaths. Each correct note opens a door little by little so they can keep going. Andy is able to play the correct notes just in time as the Fratellis are right on their heels.The Goonies escape and come to a water slide type obstacle. The treasure map turns out to be real. The Goonies find the treasure of One Eyed Willie. The Goonies start loading the treasure into their pockets. Mikey empties his marble bag and puts several jewels inside. But before they can gather any treasure and get away from the Fratellis, the Fratellis show up and capture them. Chunk and Sloth catch up to everyone and help the Goonies to escape.As the Goonies and the Fratellis escape the cave that One Eyed Willie's ship is in the cave walls begin to fall in, eventually allowing the ship to set sail again. The police find the Goonies and the Fratellis walking up the beach. The Goonies' parents are called and they all have a joyful reunion. Eventually the jewels are found in Mikey's marble bag and they help to save the homes of the Goonies' families.I was six years old when this movie came out. I loved watching this movie every chance I could. Now that I have it on DVD I can watch it every day if I want to. For a kids movie it's pretty good, even nearly thirty years old. The acting is pretty good for a bunch of child actors, not forced. The action is pretty good; the story was pretty good. A lot of comedy; a lot of laughs.

June 7th marked 30 years since the audiences first got to know the "Goonies". Whoa! Has it been so long? And is anybody still remembering this film apart from me? I honestly didn't expect there were so many people feeling so strongly about the movie, but it seems Goonies has indeed achieved cult status over the years (and decades). In retrospect, this is hardly surprising, considering the multitude of 80's films, both small and big, that have turned into classics. And Goonies exemplifies all the good qualities of the film fare of that time that made them unique. As for me, my story with the Goonies goes back a long time. I first got to see it on VHS in 1988 (apparently I was a little young to catch it in cinemas when it was first screened), instantly loved it and then by a fortunate turn of events I got to own a videotape copy of it. Over the next five years or so, it would be the subject of countless sessions, alone or with friends that got equally infected by the Goonies bug. There where times where I would get to watch it 4 times within the same day. I haven't kept track, but I figure my number of viewings must be approaching triple digits, definitely the one movie I have watched the most times, even though it isn't my favorite. From some point on I got detoxed, but even now I never decline a chance to see it again when it plays on TV. The film has also aged very very well, you can hardly tell it was shot 30 years ago, again, a testament to the production values of that time. Based on an idea by Steven Spielberg at the pinnacle of his creative period and scribed by a then up and coming Chris Columbus (before his mega-successes with Home Alone and the Harry Potter franchise), Goonies is an adventure cleverly employing good old recipes but at the same time infusing them with loads of originality. Lost pirate treasure hunt has never been done with more fun and brio than here. And the movie is also bursting with great humor and immensely quotable lines (a trade that seems to be almost extinct today), thanks to its superbly written script. Richard Donner's direction is top notch and takes full advantage of the terrific ensemble cast of all ages. Almost all of the about a dozen characters are fully fleshed-out and some of them easily turn iconic. Quite a feat for a little children's adventure! And let's not forget Dave Grusin's fabulous score. Or Cyndi Lauper!Above all else, Goonies is a film filled with the children's magic and wonder of the early Spielberg fare, and even if he is not behind the camera this time, his fingerprints on the final product are indelible. It really is a shame that similar movies are hardly made anymore today. Columbus managed to recapture some of the early Spielberg magic with the first of the Harry Potter films, it didn't last long though and wasn't picked up by other directors. I know I would definitely sign up for a new movie of this sort any day, even if I'm not a kid anymore. Sadly, most are now preoccupied with remakes and franchises instead of coming up with original ideas. I hope the Goonies is left untouched by the remake avalanche.

Child movies today are nothing compared to this classic 80s kid flck!Sure, Showtime has "Movies for Kids of All Ages" but this is truly a great kiddie flick, as well as a wonderful family film.I first saw this film in 1986, when I was around 4 years old.  My parents must have been attempting to get me and my brother into something.  I still love this film very much, even to this day, as an 18 year old.  Some of the comments on here are pretty negative.  Every American child around my age, maybe even older, has seen this at least once.I loved each character, especially Mikey, who was so cute!  Each character had a unique personality, and all of them had some memorable moments.  Two parts particularly tickled my fancy:  When Chunk is tied to a chair and is told to spill his guts, he confesses absolutely everything he has done. It's amazing what you can get from Chunk!  Also, the part where they slide out of the sewer system into the underground with the Pirate ship was classic, because Corey Felman, who as Mouth doesn't shutup, yells "F***!" when he comes out.  I actually found out how they did so many takes of that scene, and in every one of them, Feldman yelled the same word over and over. Eventually, they gave up and put it in the movie.  I also like Kerri Green as Andy, and Martha plimpton as Stef. Data and Brandon were also great characters.If you like kiddie flicks, or want to relive your childhood, I highly recommend this film!  You will love it, and it brings back many memories!That's all, I confessed everything!!!

What is entertaining about this? I fail to understand what is so great about it. I am 13, I should be the target audience. I saw this movie during a kids film camp, and everybody thought it was so hilarious that.. what? Is it funny that a fat kid jiggles his fat and that there are kids cussing and whining. What really shocks me is that the kids in the camp loved this and hated "Spirited Away". IS MY GENERATION THAT STUPID?! I'm going to analyze this film a little further to prove my point, though:ACTING: The actors themselves aren't awful, although they become so annoying at times, you kind of wanted them to die. The one playing the kid with asthma was not captivating at all. He was bland and never showed any real emotion. The others weren't bad, and they probably did the best with the script they were given, which lead to my next point...SCRIPT: Oh yeah, this is where the movie gets awful. The script is just all around unoriginal. In 4th grade,(before I saw this film), I would write adventure stories that were at the same level of this. These stories I wrote were all, honestly: There's a group of kids they go on an adventure underground involving many obstacles like:balance beams, swinging axes, etc. they find treasure, then get out and return to normal life. Sound familiar? I mean, nothing original or interesting happens. I guess you could argue that the piano scene was O.K., but even that wasn't fantastic. The characters were beyond shallow, all bogged down to just stupid quirks. They have no depth and just come off as whiny. Don't believe me? Well, how much development do they have besides fat kid-wimpy, loves food,lies Asian kid-invents things main character- asthma, whispers teenage boy- works out other kid- tries to be cool, but is annoying. YOU NEED TO DEVELOP! but the one element of the movie that really pisses me off is the deformed brother that the villains were keeping in their basement. The fact that they could stoop that low to produce comedy is just horrendous. And what was funny about him? Was it funny that he couldn't talk properly and communicated through yelling? Was it funny that he was wearing a superman shirt? No, it's actually kind of sad, and I'm surprised a lot more people don't hate this movie for exploiting people born with physical deformities like that. They deserve as much respect as people, and this just cruelly makes fun of them.EFFECTS: The main reason I gave this film such a high rating is because the effects were really great. It wasn't beautiful, it was all very brown and gray, but I guess that isn't awful. That was at least pleasing to look at.Well, this is getting pretty long, so I think I'm going to stop. To summarize; while the special effects were great, that doesn't make up for undeveloped characters, a plain, boring script and just O.K. acting. I really, REALLY hate it, but if this is what appeals to you in a film,and it appeals to a lot of people, then just keep enjoying it. Just, don't ask to me to watch it with you.

reviews.review_title: Hands up, who wants to be a Goonie...?
reviews.content: There was a time before disassociated, mean-eyed teenagers, wore hooded tops, carried knives, bothered people on street corners, and passed the time drinking cider and daisy-chaining one another. This was a time when Michael Jackson moon-walked his way into the hearts of millions, Indiana Jones cracked his whip from jungle to desert, James Bond shot and slept his way around the world without a hint of self-mocking post-modern irony, and kids watched, enjoyed, and wanted to be in, The Goonies.Written by Stephen Spielberg, and directed by Richard Donner, The Goonies is a hugely entertaining film that encapsulates the naivety and sheer sense of adventurous fun that will forever be associated with the 1980's. The film follows the adventures of six friends led by Mikey Walsh, (Sean Astin) who in the best tradition of Robert Louis Stephenson's Treasure Island, find themselves hunting for the hidden treasure of the legendary infamous pirate One Eyed Willy. This is no idle adventure however as finding the booty will enable them to save their homes which face demolition to clear the way for a luxury country club.The film works so well because along with an exciting storyline, witty script, clever balance between comedy and tension, Spielberg, Donner, and the young cast have invested it with a youthful and at times anarchic energy that grabs the audience from the opening jail break right up until the closing credits. Anne Ramsey, Joe Pantoliano, and Robert Davi, play the villainous Fratelli family with just the right mixture of fun and menace. Mama Fratelli's 'tongue' is the only thing on the menu reply to a cocky request for food by Clark 'Mouth' Devereaux (the very funny Corey Feldman) is guaranteed to garner laughs aplenty, but through closed mouths of course.As well as the obvious nod to Stephenson, the film also lends from Bond, (Ke Huy Quan's gadget inventing 'Data' models himself on 007) Indiana Jones, (Spielberg's influence can be seen throughout the film but not least in the booby-trapped hidden caves) and also The Hardy Boys, and Scooby Doo. The tradition of youngsters roving off to have adventures and solve mysteries is not new, it can be seen in Ransome's Swallows and Amazons, Blyton's The Famous Five, Hitchcok's The Three Investigators, Lewis's Narnia books, and many other sources. They have all gripped our collective imagination at one stage or another and happily The Goonies does the same.The success of the film is helped in no small way by the impressive set design and location of the film in the leafy town of Astoria, Oregon. If ever there was a place in which adventure was to be had Astoria is it. Sit back then, relax, and free yourself of cynicism, because as an audience it is 'our time' to enjoy the magic that is The Goonies.

The Goonies is a perfect example of everything that is wrong with society. The title is perfect, as these kids are indeed Goons in every sense of the word.How can parents take their kids to see such a violent, harsh movie. When the Goonies go "wilding", and rob, beat, and terrorize the innocent townsfolk, well, call me horrified. I say that, because, I was, uh, horrified.
The only thing about this movie that I liked was the previews, when the Soda Pop danced with the Popcorn. That was delightful! Indeed!Much like Faces of Death, and The Wayne Brady Show, Goonies is a bad influence for today's youth and should be banned worldwide.

reviews.review_title: This movie stands the test of time
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies of all time. I fell in love with it as a young kid the first time I watched it on television with my younger sister.The cast works perfectly for this story, the comedy is top notch and appeal lasts forever. One of the best things about the Goonies is so many of us have become a "Goonie". I myself use the name in most of my monikers including for these reviews here at IMDb.With the advancement of film making capabilities The Goonies is starting to look dated, but I still enjoy every minute of it. My wife and I can usually snap out of any bad mood or "funk" when we see Chunk and the Gang get together in this teenage riot.

This movie now qualifies as one of the most underrated movies ever. The Goonies was an entertaining adventure movie with alot of laughs, and a 6.9 doesn't do it justice.Sean Astin did a very good job on this movie for his age at the time. Corey Feldman and Jeff Cohen provided some great comic relief.The music was pretty good, and there was alot of eye candy that kept me in awe.I gave this movie a 10/10, as it IS a very good movie. It may be among my favorites. Good job, Spielberg.

The Goonies is an enjoyable adventure about a group of kids going on a treasure hunt, so they can save their homes from land developers. The kids are quite entertaining and funny, some more than others, but they're all memorable. There's also lots of suspense and thrills. It's so cool that this is finally coming out on DVD. I can't wait for that. Overall, an enjoyable adventure that will never grow old. *** (out of four)

reviews.review_title: A Film that takes you back to the carefree days of childhood
reviews.content: The Goonies is a film that I think can be enjoyed by people of all ages, unless you're a pretentious film snob who will dismiss any film that wasn't made by Ingmar Bergman, Federico Fellini, Vittorio De Sica or Stanley Kubrick. The Goonies certainly isn't by any stretch a groundbreaking piece of cinematic history or a masterpiece deemed worthy of mountainous praise, but it is a movie that is cherished by children and adults alike for its simple, but lovable qualities.To keep it brief, the plot follows a group of children living in the Goon Docks suburb who are forced to move away from their homes that they love to make room for the development of a golf course. The children discover an old treasure map that supposedly leads to a fortune in precious stones and jewelery and so they go looking for it to save their homes.A very basic premise, but that isn't the only source of the film's appeal. The characters Mikey, Mouth, Data, Chunk etc are all lovable and are played wonderfully by some of the best child actors ever. Sean Astin (Lord of the Rings) and Corey Feldman (Stand By Me) especially. The other characters are very likable and all deliver great performances In combination with a likable cast of characters and a dire situation, The Goonies has a strong adventurous quality that cannot be easily replicated in a film such as this. The comedic value, although often very cheesy, is very high, notably the antics of Chunk.You'd think that I grew up with this movie considering the positive comments I have about it, but I really didn't. I only saw the film a year ago and instantly fell in love with it. It's a film that perfectly reminds us of the wonders of childhood and why children should appreciate the limited moments they have. It's also a film that manages to cheer me up regardless of how upset I may feel. Because of this, The Goonies demands infinite rewatches.It does sadden me that my parents never exposed me to The Goonies as a child, but I know that after experiencing it again and again, I will not make the same mistake and I sincerely hope that after reading my review that you will do the same. The creative minds of both Richard Donner (Lethal Weapon, Superman, The Omen) and Steven Spielberg (Jaws, Raiders of the Lost Ark, Schindler's List) should be praised.The Goonies is a film that takes you out of a complicated world, spiritually transports you back to childhood and entertains you marvelously from the opening scene to the end credits. I love this movie and if you're willing to lighten up, I'm sure you will too. Thank you for reading my review.10/10
Brilliant for anyone. Even kids now will love it.Characters are brilliant. Makes you wonder if no sequel was a missed opportunity

This movie is just great.  Its Classic.  Everytime i watch this movie I fall in love with it again.  Its just that good.  The kids are the best, they make the movie what it is...Chunk, Mouth, Mikey, Data..all of em', theyre all awesome just like the movie.  This movie is Classic to me and i know many other people feel the same way.  It has everything a movie should have, Its a heart filled fantasy with comedy, action, thrills and it makes you feel good...and thats what a movie should do.  I recommend this to anyone who wants to have a great time watching a movie. 10/10.
Do yourself a favour and never watch this film. It is so annoying and disjointed.

Goonies depicts the story of a bunch of kids that are forced to leave home and decide to have one last adventure, and this time based on a legend of a pirate who went missing and had hidden treasure. This is a fun classic 80's styled film and quite the cute adventure. Between a beautiful opening sequence to the film the audience already becomes intrigued about what is next and what do those characters have to do with the main cast of kids. reviews.review_title: A fun adventure film the whole family can enjoy.
reviews.content: It has been years since I saw "The Goonies", when I was 10 years old back in 1985, it was one of my favorite movies. I recently found the movie on DVD, and it still has all the charm and fun that I remember.The Goonies are a group of friends who's families are being evicted from their homes by a rich family to make way for a new country club. On a typical Saturday afternoon, the boys find a treasure map in their father's attic, and decide to try to track down the treasure to save their homes.With a great fun story, classic comedy lines, "The Goonies" is definitely a film that the whole family can watch. It is interesting to see Sean Astin as a young boy. How different he looked! Josh Brolin was also great.This is your typical 80's film, but is timeless and still stands up today. Check it out with your kids. It is worth the effort to find on DVD.

I just watched the DVD last night, I am totally impressed.  If you are a fan, go and get the DVD today! The menus are fun to play with, the special features include outtakes (including the infamous octopus scene), full length commentary featuring donner, and all the goonies (except sloth, who is deceased).  The best feature is the two part music video for Cyndi Lauper's "Good Enough" song. If you've never seen it, i'll describe it: it features lots of the original WWF wrestlers (remember when wrestlers were like super heroes and super villians not just a bunch of oversized rednecks?) like Andre The Giant and Rowdy Roddy Piper! The dvd is presented in widescreen, so you get that great movie experience you come to expect from DVDs.  The cut is remastered, of course.Nostalgia is very important with a movie like this.  It might not have the most original plot, or the best acting, but for anyone who grew up with this movie, it's possible that this movie can instil the greatest feeling of nostalgia in us 20 somethings.  I practically have to hold back the tears everytime I hear "good enough."  Having the music video to remind me of those old saturday afternoon wrestling matches, a making of feature, and a brilliantly restored print, really brings out the nostalgia. Now if only they'd make that sequel!

reviews.review_title: Find the child inside yourself! (not in a Gary Glitter sense)
reviews.content: The Goonies is one of those brilliant little films that are best watched on a rainy sunday afternoon*The sense of adventure that Donner creates is brilliant (I would suspect that the insight into child psychology Spielberg has helped him along the way, however).  The pacing of the film and its set-up is perfection - the children have seeminly no way to save their beloved homes (the most important place to yound adolescents) but their is a glimmer of hope with a fluke attic based discovery; and we've all, at some stage, gone snooping around in the attic looking for treasure (usually only finding our dad's secret porn stashes, sadly).The Fratellis are the best crime family ever created (after the Corleones) it really is as simple as that.  Check out Ma Fratelli giving a young Sean Austin (Mikey) a glass of whisky, and when he looks on in shock, stating "It's wet ain't it!"Sloth is a living god, as is everyones favourite chuck-a-lunk Lawrence "Chunk".  Fieldman shines as "Mouth".My only problem with the film is that it was not made with the intention of ageing well - its cleary an eighties film - which is no bad thing if you are a buff of the era, but may be hard to stomach if you're new to the film.A bit of a sleeper hit, and a modern classic. 7/10  Highly recommend it.*For imdb users in Africa and India this may not apply.

A group of kids who are about to be evicted from their homes discover a treasure map and get involved in an adventure involving pirates(Well, dead ones), a family of gangsters, buried treasure, and of course, intricate booby traps. This is an adventure that everybody wanted to go on as a kid, and is fully realized in this fine film. The acting is excellent, especially considering the sheer amount of child actors. Many didn't go on to have much of a career after this film though, except maybe Sean Astin, Josh Brolin and Martha Plimpton. As for the adults, they Fratelli's manage to be both sinister and somewhat comedic at the same time-fans of 007 and The Matrix might recognize the two brothers-Robert Davi(Jake) went on to play the sinister Sanchez in 1989's "License to Kill", and Joe Pantolino(Francis) went on to play Cypher in "The Matrix", although he's barely recognizable.  From the Cyndia Lauper song to the fashions, this film has 80's written all over it, and is a huge nostalgia trip for many of the kid's who grew up during that interesting decade. A great film!

(sarcasm intended)) the kids wont imitate that impossible stuff. And sure the villains malformed son might scare kids.
